Freud was simply making explicit the principles we ordinarily use when making intuitive judgments about other people.
People dismiss Freud's theories, despite their staggering explanatory power, because they don't want to be told they lie to themselves.
Nobody is perfectly transparent to himself; nobody is conscious of everything in his mind.
One can readily become conscious of some previously unconscious mental constituents without resistance; these are "preconscious."
When one represses an entity, one doesn't destroy it; one merely blinds oneself to it.
A repressed desire cannot be discharged unless it employs a subterfuge.
Repressed desires can disguise themselves as desires the subject consciously wishes to act on.
Repressed desires can be expressed as symptoms.
Arguments against Freudian psychology are pitifully weak and involve regressions to crude, demonstrably false positions.
The views that "we're computers," "there is no consciousness," "there are no minds," and "the mind is completely transparent to itself" are willful denials of the obvious.
While it's a good idea not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not a good idea not to impute them to people.
The projector itself cannot be a projection; the mind cannot be eliminated from the scientific picture.
One can partly de-operationalize beliefs one doesn't want by choosing not to delineate their consequences.
One can isolate a belief‚Äîprevent it from engaging bodies of belief it would otherwise engage and from begetting beliefs it would otherwise beget.
By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
One can choose to look for reasons to have beliefs opposed to those one wishes one didn't have, like a lawyer building a case for a client known to be guilty.
Even though one can't directly choose one's beliefs, one can choose to do things that make it harder to attend to a given belief than to withdraw attention from it.
Most data-synthesis occurs below the threshold of consciousness.
The sub-personal gathering and processing of information is more fundamental than personal gathering and processing; minds are more basic than selves.
One's decisions about what goes on in one's mind are of limited scope, affecting how conscious strata communicate with other strata but not directly affecting deeper strata.

Contemporary theoretical psychology's denial of emotions and repression is itself thoroughly emotional and an instance of repression‚Äîa rationalization serving to keep unwanted self-knowledge at bay.
The claim that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.
The apparent paradox of repression (that one must be conscious of what one represses) dissolves once one distinguishes repression‚ÇÅ from repression‚ÇÇ.
The natures of both conscious and unconscious forces involved in repression‚ÇÅ differ from those involved in repression‚ÇÇ.
Rationalization-construction is more heavily involved in keeping ideas repressed than in initially repressing them.
The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind: its disunity, the distinction between acquaintance and description, and the ambiguity of "conscious."
The right hand of the mind doesn't always know what the left is doing.
One can unwittingly have two divergent attitudes towards a single propositional attitude of one's own.
Given only that two conscious events are derivatives of some propositional attitude, it doesn't follow that any one part of one's mind has the information needed to recognize that attitude in both.
Were one's belief that 1+1=2 inoperative whenever not blazing a trail across consciousness, one's way of dealing with the world would bear little resemblance to one's actual way.
Supposing knowledge is identical with some physiological structure, that structure is psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness‚Äînot just as a heap of molecules.
One can have thoughts about Charlemagne and thus have a concept of him, yet fail to recognize him if one met him.
So long as one didn't figure out who Charlemagne was upon meeting him, one would unwittingly have two distinct concepts of him.
One can discover that the gnawing feeling of unpleasantness experienced when somebody mentions Smith is one's detestation of Smith.
One can be acquainted with a given one of one's own mental contents while also having descriptive knowledge of it.
One can discover that one actually has some attitude towards a mental entity that one did not previously know oneself to have.
What one is directly given in consciousness are various indications that one has a particular emotion, not the emotion per se.
Even when indications of an emotion are strong enough to leave no room for reasonable doubt, one still must "synthesize" them by making a judgment.
In most cases, the judgment that synthesizes emotional indications is made so automatically that one is unaware any judgment has been made.
When a propositional attitude is emotionally sterile‚Äîconcerning number-theory or epistemology‚Äîwe have no trouble making the needed judgments about it.
Evidences of a propositional attitude may be dispersed over time and occur in multifarious contexts.
Part (b) of the conventional conception of repression‚Äîthat repressed content constantly struggles to break into consciousness‚Äîis paradoxical as stated.
The paradox arises because keeping content out of consciousness would seem to require knowing what that content is.
The conventional conception incorrectly describes repression as an operation performed on existing beliefs rather than a failure to form beliefs.
Repression‚ÇÅ involves choosing not to learn something that, if learned and therefore known, one would wish one had never learned‚Äîbut only after it was too late.
Every case of repression‚ÇÅ does involve intrapsychic conflict, as the conventional conception says.
Contrary to the conventional conception, the conflict in repression‚ÇÅ is not between unconscious knowledge of truth T and conscious ignorance of T.
The conflict in repression‚ÇÅ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know the truth.
One can choose activities that flood the judgment-making faculty with information concerning judgments one wants to avoid making.
One can choose to do things that deplete the judgment-making faculty of energy it needs to function (e.g., intense exercise for hours).
One can choose to paralyze the physiological underpinnings of judgments (e.g., by getting drunk) or permanently damage them (e.g., by lobotomy).
One cannot directly choose what to believe; one can only choose what to believe in the way one can choose to gain weight.
Within limits, one can choose which beliefs to make operational and which to make non-operational.
One can choose to do things that make a given belief impotent and irrelevant.
One can choose an occupation in which a lack of some ability is irrelevant, thereby making one's knowledge of that lack irrelevant.
What it would take to convince you that somebody you're not married to is cheating on his wife is minuscule compared to what it would take to convince you that your husband is cheating.
Because evolution implies we're meaningless orangutans, we won't judge it worthy of acceptance until it's met absurdly high standards of evidence.
Denying that orangutans are our biological kin is like denying that the person with grape jelly and crumbs around his mouth ate your jelly-doughnut.
If you read Freud and then study a single person's behavior for around 10 minutes, it becomes clear his theories are theoretically conservative.
People don't want to part with rationalizations; they'd rather be a king in their dreams than a janitor in reality.
The opposition to Freud's claims involves regressions to crude positions: "We're computers" (Fodor), "There is no consciousness" (Dennett), "There are no minds" (Quine).
Searle's view that the mind is completely transparent to itself is a willful denial of the obvious.
The Churchlands' view that nobody believes, doubts, or hopes for anything‚Äîthat propositional attitude terms belong to "folk-psychology"‚Äîis demonstrably false.
The Dretske-Fodor view that there is no difference between a concept of a person and a photograph of that person is risible.
These flights into inanity are touted as "scientific" and "rigorous" under the pretense of completing science's victory over animism.
While it's good not to impute minds to stones, the projector‚Äîthe mind itself‚Äîcannot be a projection.
For one's knowledge of an ugly truth to be repressed‚ÇÇ, that knowledge, when taken with other accepted propositions, entails a more generic proposition.
The more generic proposition can be kept in consciousness without having to overhaul one's entire life.
The generic proposition is sufficiently vague that knowledge of it won't make one retch at the sight of the problematic object.
One can realize one wishes one hadn't discovered an ugly truth while also realizing that mere suppression won't suffice.
One can resolve that, when confronted with data that led to the ugly belief, one will model it in a way consistent with the generic belief but not with the specific ugly truth.
Beliefs are inert except to the extent that one draws consequences from them and that they are allowed to beget or engage other beliefs.
The making of inferences at least sometimes involves deliberate, conscious effort.
Some inferences are made involuntarily; insights often just occur to one based on rational consideration of evidence.
Even though many inferences are made involuntarily, one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one's mind makes.
One can so structure one's life that it is very unlikely one will consciously make inferences from a belief that one would otherwise make.
One can so structure one's life that a belief, though still conscious, is isolated‚Äîprevented from engaging bodies of belief and from begetting beliefs it otherwise would.
Such an isolated belief is conscious in some formal sense but has become inert at the level of consciousness, like knowledge of some random, uninteresting fact.
By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have anything more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
One can know that people are being tortured without knowing what that proposition amounts to as well as someone who witnessed torture.
Even if technically no less aware of a truth than someone with first-hand knowledge, one's awareness can mean very little compared to theirs.
First-hand knowledge transforms abstract awareness into something that means a great deal.
Knowledge of complex interpersonal truths is not derived from some one sense-perception; such truths can't be known that directly.
Such knowledge embodies inference to the best explanation.
Unless knowledge can be acquired through inferences to the best explanation, what we actually know is only an infinitesimally small part of what we think we know.
Given a body of data, it is more likely than not that there is more than one reasonable or semi-reasonable way to model it.
An alternative model of data need not be optimal; it need only be far from obviously false to serve repression‚ÇÇ.
By deciding not to draw inferences from an ugly belief, one becomes more likely to take aberrant phenomena on a case-by-case basis.
Bits of knowledge that would otherwise congregate will remain isolated from one another when one resolves not to synthesize them.
As a result of isolation, one's appreciation of what an ugly truth entails will remain superficial.
One will be slow to recognize the consequences of an ugly truth for one's own welfare.
By isolating a belief, one ensures that energy and thought that would deepen understanding of its consequences are diverted to a fool's errand.
The response of modeling data in terms of a preferred alternative soon becomes automatic, like an actor's rehearsed lines.
This automatic response-mechanism further isolates the knowledge one wishes to suppress.
One cannot uninstall a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness, just as one typically cannot uninstall a computer program by dragging the desktop icon to the garbage.
Beliefs are enduring structures; they do a lot of work even when not consciously deployed.
If one really stopped knowing that 1+1=2, one's way of dealing with the world would suddenly change radically, pervading practically every field of endeavor.
A belief isn't like a mood or other will-o'-the-wisps that populate consciousness.
Like any enduring structure constitutive of one's metabolism, one has at most partial control over a belief's fortunes.
The conscious representative of a repressed‚ÇÇ belief becomes an innocuous shell‚Äîit has been repressed, but it still lives on.
A repressed‚ÇÇ belief "presses for discharge" (Freud's term).
Since one no longer acknowledges a repressed‚ÇÇ belief's existence, it cannot be discharged through intentional behavior.
A repressed‚ÇÇ belief must insinuate itself into one's intentions without one's knowing it.
Displacement occurs when repressed rage at one person is expressed as meanness toward another (e.g., rage at father displaced onto students).
A repressed‚ÇÇ belief can be expressed as a symptom‚Äîe.g., crippling anxiety when encountering situations reminiscent of what was repressed.
To keep something repressed‚ÇÇ, one must be able to identify it‚Äîbut if one can identify it, one is conscious of it and it's not repressed.
The resolution of this paradox involves retaining knowledge of a generic proposition while repressing the specific ugly truth.
By accepting a generic version of an ugly truth, one's conscious disposition isn't completely antagonistic to the rational side urging acceptance of the specific truth.
Accepting the generic version means one isn't locked into a draining struggle with the forces of rationality and truthfulness within oneself.
At the same time, accepting the generic version neutralizes the message those forces are trying to convey.
This strategy spares one painful realizations and the labor-intensive changes they demand.
The science of psychology has itself become little more than a means by which people rationalize attempts to repress knowledge of obvious psychodynamic facts.
Many claim the unconscious is an artifact of dated psychoanalytic theories superseded by "rigorous" physiological studies.
The thoroughly hypocritical and self-deceptive character of such pronouncements is evident when examining the judgments and conduct of these naysayers.
Not a single judgment these naysayers make about others concerns physiological underpinnings; they concern psychology.
PET-scan findings would be of no psychological interest unless correlated with independently known psychological facts.
If mental activity were discovered to be mediated by the gall-bladder, PET-scans would immediately cease to be of psychological interest.
Brain-science, to the extent it's relevant to psychology, is parasitic on psychological knowledge.
Most opponents of psychodynamic psychology provide no arguments other than empty slogans that "science" studies brains, not intangibles like emotions.
Whatever we know about the external world‚Äîabout brains, neurons‚Äîwe know through perceptions and thoughts, i.e., through alleged "intangibles."
While brains may be ontologically more basic than thoughts, thoughts and perceptions are epistemologically more basic than brains.
"Brain" is a theoretical term; characterizing something as a brain ascribes functions one cannot know it discharges without theory-soaked extrapolation.
"Brain" is deeply entrenched in well-confirmed theory, hence the illusion that it is non-theoretical.
Psychological "intangibles" are epistemologically much more tangible than "tangible" things like brains.
The existence of psychological intangibles is infinitely less dubitable than that of brains.
The denial of emotions is itself a thoroughly emotional position.
The denial of repression is itself an instance of repression.
Those who deny emotions and repression claim to be "scientific," but such dishonesty and obtuseness doesn't deserve that characterization.
Hyper-intelligent people are quite as prone to not seeing themselves for who they are as their less gifted brethren.
Given that intelligence doesn't protect against self-ignorance, it is scientifically de rigueur to suppose another factor is operative.
That other factor is obvious: people don't want to see themselves for who they are, so they don't.
Sartre held there is no unconscious mental activity and a fortiori no repression.
Sartre's position was that the mind is completely and utterly transparent to itself, immediate and complete access to all contents being essential to mentality.
Unlike other deniers of the unconscious, Sartre actually argued for his position.
Sartre's argument is initially persuasive: one must know what one is trying to keep out of consciousness to succeed, but that knowledge makes one conscious of it.
Given Sartre's argument, either he is right and his reasoning cogent, or he is wrong and the fallacy must be pinpointed.
The specific forms self-deception and repression can take may not be the forms they actually take.
There are elements of truth in the models presented for repression‚ÇÅ and repression‚ÇÇ.
It is a philosophical task of the utmost urgency to make clear what is wrong with Sartre's powerful argument.
It is equally urgent to make clear what exactly self-deception and repression involve.
Philosophers have neglected these tasks, encouraging psychology to go down blind alleys of scientism and methodological incoherence.
OCD is a prolongation into adulthood of the child's binary emotional relation to the world.
All children are OCD.
OCD children have specific rituals not shared by other children.
OCD is not eliminated by confronting it head-on.
OCD arises from emotional vulnerability caused by actual defenselessness.
OCD is about withdrawal from a frightening world into a safe space of thought and ritual.
The way to conquer OCD is to conquer fear.
Philosophers and obsessive-compulsives are both compulsive doubters.
Philosophers and obsessive-compulsives rationalize their doubt as rigor.
Both types are impotent and fearful of engaging the world.
Their potency lies in manipulating linguistic or symbolic proxies of reality.
They internalize the world into thought where they have total power.
Both are preoccupied with logical niceties and fine points of argumentation.
This preoccupation derives from a sense of impotence.
Their doubts about the external world are displaced doubts about the internal world.
Both are driven by rage, narcissism, and fear, not rationality.
Their intellectualism cloaks a dark psychological condition.
Both are pathologically concerned with ethics because they are crypto-criminals.
Philosophers tend to be extremely sensitive to linguistic niceties.
A disproportionate number of philosophers are professional-level musicians.
Philosophical skepticism is an excuse to remain holed up in one‚Äôs mind.
Skepticism allows retreat from external threats into the safety of consciousness.
The skeptic‚Äôs retreat requires paralyzing thought to avoid returning to reality.
Obsessive-compulsives use doubt to avoid action.
Obsessions arise because the obsessive-compulsive has nothing else to do.
Compulsions are the mind‚Äôs way of pushing one back into the world.
Compulsions represent the sane side of the obsessive-compulsive.
OCD is about refusal to act and defensive withdrawal into consciousness.
The obsessive-compulsive sees reality clearly but is fearful.
An essential part of OCD treatment is accepting one‚Äôs sadistic/masochistic sexuality.
Mental illness involves withdrawal from reality.
Psychoses destroy coherence of ideation; neuroses paralyze the will.
Neuroses estrange intellection from emotional concomitants.
The obsessive-compulsive‚Äôs intellect is hyper-coherent but will is atrophied.
Restoring the thought-feeling balance eliminates OCD.
Psychopaths have no conscience.
Institutional psychopathization occurs when an entire institution becomes psychopathic.
Many university departments and psychotherapy branches are psychopathic.
Most psychopaths today are bureaucrats, not con-men.
Bureaucrats surrender all decision-making to the institution.
Bureaucrats are not internally conflicted.
Bureaucrats have psychological fault lines that are schisms, not conflicts.
Bureaucrats respond to insight with pure hatred, not resistance.
Bureaucrats are non-rogue psychopaths; psychopaths are rogue bureaucrats.
Psychopaths pass lie detector tests because they don‚Äôt believe anything.
Double-think is possible only for those who believe nothing.
Double-think is shifting between socially mandated acceptances, not beliefs.
The bureaucrat‚Äôs hands are tied because he cannot act‚Äîonly follow orders.
Academic specialization is an artificial, cowardly bureaucratic division.
Howard Gardner‚Äôs theory of multiple intelligences is absurd and destructive.
Intelligence can migrate and reinvent itself across domains.
OCD is on the rise due to bureaucratic bloat in education and law.
OCD results from using legalistic protocols to suppress emotions.
More bureaucracy leads to more suppressed rage, which fuels OCD.
Women have externalized superegos; men have internalized ones.
A woman‚Äôs superego requires reinforcement from morally centered men.
Submitting to a psychopathic feminist reinforces her psychopathy.
Being firm and principled helps restore a woman‚Äôs superego function.
OCD provides relief from intense anxiety.
OCD is a defense mechanism that eventually does more harm than good.
The obsessive-compulsive must choose between anxiety relief and growth.
OCD is ultimately voluntary‚Äîan affliction of the will.
Symptoms are involuntary only relative to a choice to remain in a defensive bubble.
The prognosis for OCD is positive if seen as a voluntary condition.
Having a purpose in life is the way to beat OCD.
People need a purpose to endure pain and strive.
OCD reflects a bifurcated psychological structure without a master plan.
A grand purpose resolves internal conflicts and eliminates OCD.
OCD arises from alienation from one‚Äôs true purpose.
OCD is not a disease like cancer; it afflicts the will.
The obsessive-compulsive has a damaged will, not a damaged body.
OCD symptoms stem from a stalemate between id and superego.
The obsessive-compulsive can act but chooses not to due to anxiety.
Psychoanalysis must direct the will, not just interpret conflicts.
Social anxiety is about repressed rage toward others.
Social anxiety keeps one away from people because of hatred, not fear.
Recognizing the anger beneath social anxiety allows it to be properly directed.
Acquiring power or sublimating misanthropy can cure social anxiety.
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is just behavior modification.
Structural therapy changes the obsessive-compulsive‚Äôs reality orientation.
Effective therapists must project inner strength and have overcome their own demons.
Therapeutic rapport depends on the patient‚Äôs belief in the therapist‚Äôs healing power.
People with OCD often have severe reading difficulties due to psychological resistance.
Reading problems occur with content-rich material, especially psychological texts.
OCD-driven reading rituals are resistance to self-understanding.
Early resolution of reading problems is crucial for intellectual development.
CBT alone is insufficient because OCD will produce new symptoms.
OCD is a flight from reality into symbolic proxies.
Treatment must address the underlying fear-driven withdrawal from reality.
OCD can be turned against itself using its own binary, all-or-nothing nature.
Obsessive-compulsives have neural plasticity beneath their rigidity.
One should use OCD‚Äôs binariness to force growth-critical changes.
The right question is not how to get over OCD, but where it is an asset.
OCD involves high intelligence and sensitivity misapplied in toxic contexts.
Intrusive thoughts are the mind‚Äôs protest against self-castration.
Having a goal in life organizes mental energy and eliminates intrusive thoughts.
Obsessive-compulsives are aware of their compulsions, unlike others.
Mental illnesses are contextual and can be assets in the right environment.
Psychiatric Munchausen by proxy involves parents falsely diagnosing children for attention.
Auto-hypnosis is essential for action; rationalization perverts judgment.
Psychosis is a mental impairment precipitated by a break with external reality.
Neurosis is a mental impairment precipitated by a break with one‚Äôs emotional condition.
The neurotic flees from his emotions; the psychotic flees from reality.
Neurosis may blunt awareness of external reality, but this is subordinate to loss of emotional awareness.
Psychosis may disrupt emotional understanding, but this is subordinate to loss of awareness of external reality.
Psychosis involves a partial regression to psychological infancy.
An infant is not psychotic because its psychological integration is consistent, not split.
The adult psychotic has two incompatible ways of processing information: adult and infantile.
The psychotic lacks a unified value system and is in psychological disarray.
Neurosis involves repressing threats to integration by burying their emotional valence.
The neurotic has relatively unimpaired intellectual awareness.
Neurosis may heighten intellectual awareness as compensation for emotional impoverishment.
The neurotic‚Äôs psyche is hyper-stable but ossified.
Psychosis is an inability to organize consciously experienced emotion.
Neurosis is an inability to have consciously experienced emotion.
Psychosis paralyzes through a superabundance of emotion; neurosis through a lack of emotion.
For men, happiness is about forging one‚Äôs own identity.
For women, happiness is about being loved.
A man is happy if he triumphs over his father by not submitting to him.
A woman is happy if her father loved her.
A man can establish identity by doing the opposite of his father.
A man can establish identity by doing what his father does, but better.
A man can fail by trying to fill his father‚Äôs shoes but failing.
A man can fail by submitting to his father without trying to fill his shoes.
A man can fail by having no father at all.
Schopenhauer triumphed over his merchant father by becoming a philosopher.
Mozart triumphed over his composer father by becoming a greater composer.
Donald Trump triumphed over his moderately successful father by being extremely successful.
Compulsive work is about avoidance.
A workaholic who loves his work is not working compulsively.
A workaholic who hates his work is working compulsively to avoid what he truly wants.
Stuttering is about not speaking with a single voice.
Stuttering occurs when two distinct currents of thought are evenly matched in controlling speech.
Normal speech occurs when one thought-current dominates.
Men are self-contained; women are not.
Men who are not self-contained are not really men.
Women who are self-contained are not really women.
One does not learn from failure; one learns from adversity.
Failure is the end-result of adversity not triumphed over.
Success opens new vistas; failure is a dead end.
Everybody wants money, even those who spurn it.
The monk or ‚Äústarving artist‚Äù who spurns money has an overblown, reactive relationship to it.
Overblown feelings are the opposite of what they seem.
Emotions that are genuine are not objects of intense self-scrutiny.
The #1 rule of writing is to immediately write down every thought that occurs.
If you wait, the moment and the unconscious constellation behind the thought will be lost.
The #1 rule of writing is also complete honesty, which is achieved by writing thoughts immediately.
Lack of coordination stems from a failure to be centered and to have a true objective.
A psychological condition is pathological if it restricts freedom.
A condition is positively counter-pathological if it augments freedom, even if unusual.
The expression "the intentions of the framers" denotes an idealization, not an empirical actuality, since the various framers had numerically and qualitatively different minds.
When the word "they" is part of an expression meant to denote a collective attitude, it denotes an idealization rather than an empirical reality.
Originalism is exceedingly dubious if the term "intentions" is understood in purely individualistic, psychological terms.
If originalism is to hold water, "the intentions of the framers" must refer to the intentions of some kind of collective entity.
The intentions of the framers cannot be understood strictly in terms of the psychologies of the framers taken individually.

The originalist position collapses into circularity: Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of the intentions of the framers, but the intentions of the framers are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.
An idealization is by definition something that has no precise counterpart in the spatiotemporal world.

When discussing what Jefferson would have said about constitutional issues, we are not making an empirical statement about what the actual Jefferson would have said, but rather an a priori proposition about what he should have said given his values.

The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use a counterfactual to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but he cannot run the counterfactual until he has identified those values.

Jefferson's values are definable independently of any views of Constitutional interpretation, but the expression "Jefferson's values" itself denotes an idealization as opposed to a psychological reality.
Like many complex human beings, Jefferson had many values, and while some may have been fair-minded and egalitarian, others may have been retrograde and misogynist.

When we say that Jefferson was not being "true to his values," the word "his" doesn't denote Thomas Jefferson the human being but rather an idealization of Jefferson purged of his 18th century prejudices.
Even the finest minds are marred by ugly biases.

When we talk about what Jefferson would have said, we are talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said‚Äîone who didn't suffer from the cultural limitations and random neuroses that mar even the best of minds.
Once we start dealing with an idealization of Jefferson's psyche, as opposed to his actual psyche, we have replaced empirical propositions about psychology with a priori propositions about values.
People with borderline personality disorder have two distinct, simultaneously operative psychological "operating systems"‚Äîone appropriately adult and sane, the other infantile in nature.
One part of the BPD person's mind remained "stuck" or "fixated" at an early phase of life, usually very early childhood, while the other part advanced to maturity.
The fixation in BPD typically results from a trauma, usually sexual molestation.
People with BPD oscillate between their adult and infantile psychological integrations.
The rapid oscillation between two modalities makes BPD individuals appear to be lying or "playing games," when in fact they are shifting between two distinct and incongruent worldviews.
People with BPD are not psychopaths, despite sometimes acting in entitled, limitlessly self-serving narcissistic ways.

The difference between BPD and psychopathy: the psychopath is simply a phony who sometimes puts on a mask of sanity and decency, while the BPD person is genuinely two-sided, with neither side being a mask.
The preferred psychological defense mechanism in BPD is splitting rather than repression.
The BPD personality-structure is itself the result of splitting.

Repression involves having a single psychological architecture and shoving incompatible conceits into the unconscious, while splitting involves shifting between one's adult side and one's infantile side.
The normal person's psyche keeps its infantilism in the abyss of the unconscious, while the BPD person's psyche keeps infantilisms in a concurrently operative sphere of mental activity.
The essence of borderline personality disorder is that splitting takes the place of repression.
When the psychopath acts non-psychopathically, it is because he is just acting; when the BPD person acts non-psychopathically, it is because she is being true to one side of her personality.
When the BPD person acts psychopathically, it is because she is regressing and her infantile side is dominating, not because a mask has fallen.
Most people, including most psychologists, wrongly assume that group psychology is to be understood in terms of individual psychology.
The standard view that individuals have self-directed drives that are somehow diverted in group contexts cannot be reconciled with the incredibly high degree of conformism exhibited by people.
The deference given by people to convention, pre-existing custom, and fleeting but powerful fads cannot be explained in terms of fear of others alone.

Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in the behavior of collectives, it is hard to believe that collectives are merely the result of individuals pursuing their respective paths.
The collective is the primary thing, biologically speaking, and there is an illusion of individual choice and indeed of individualism per se.

Individual cells can be better understood if we recognize that they individually try to survive, flourish, and reproduce only to the extent that their doing so is necessary for the collectives formed thereby to survive, flourish, and reproduce.
Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
Person-individualism can be explained in terms of person-collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
Bona fide individuals‚Äîgeniuses who think for themselves‚Äîcan be seen as limiting cases of collectives, as collectives of one, or as rogue actors with an unusual office within a collective.
The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong.
It is very hard to explain group behavior on the assumption that collectives represent averages of the behaviors of so many self-contained existentialist autonomous deciders.

Outside of contexts involving immediate threats to physical well-being or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores to be accounted for by the hypothesis that collectives are indeed collectives of bona fide individuals.
Before the 1929 Stock Market Crash, the nation's financial system was highly unregulated, leading to improprieties that caused the Crash.
The Fed responded to the Stock Market Crash by tightening monetary policy, which exacerbated the situation and led to a full-blown economic depression.
Glass-Steagall prohibited commercial banks from functioning as investment banks, thereby preventing banks from using customer funds to finance their own ventures.
The repeal of Glass-Steagall in 1999 and the deregulation of the derivatives market in 2004 eliminated the firewalls put in place after the 1929 Crash.
The 2001 Dot Bomb Crash resulted from banks investing in substandard tech startups, and the 2008 Housing Crash resulted from banks investing in worthless derivatives contracts.
A derivative is a contract whose value is a function of the value of some other security, and most derivatives are highly leveraged, highly risky, and difficult to value.
The price of a home tends to stay close to its value, but with securities there is very little short-term relationship between price and value‚Äîthe two can diverge without limit instantaneously.
When real-estate debts were bundled into financial securities like MBS's, the market could make them far more valuable than the underlying assets, and could do so in hours.
Once mortgages were securitized, investment banks had enormous incentives to drive up the number of home loans issued, regardless of the quality of those loans.
Bubbles can only last so long; eventually prices and values converge when demand fails to keep pace with supply.
The 2008 crisis was really two distinct crises: a housing crisis that decreased wealth and a banking crisis that diminished credit.
Economies depend on credit as much as they do on wealth; when businesses cannot borrow, they fail and the economy fails.
The Volcker Rule does not categorically prohibit banks from engaging in proprietary trading but requires that they match customer funds with their own funds when doing so.
The Volcker Rule prohibits banks from partnering with hedge funds and private equity firms to limit the extent to which large banks can endanger themselves and the market.
The Fed's role as a regulatory agency is ambiguous, since unlike every other financial regulatory agency, it is partly made up of the very entities it is supposed to regulate.
Given that three banks own over 75% of the Fed's shares, the Fed has at best a serious conflict of interest and at worst has no existence separate from the banks that own it.
Financial regulation has done a great deal of good and very little harm; financial deregulation has done a great deal of harm and very little good.
The Fed is in the practice of managing self-generated crises.
We cannot expect banks to self-regulate, and we therefore cannot expect the Fed to self-regulate to the extent that it is owned by banks.
In the United States, financial regulations have decentralized access to capital, keeping the economy going, while financial deregulation has hindered the economy by centralizing access to capital.
Even by the lights of a radical free marketeer, financial regulation has been a success because it has decentralized access to capital.
The Sorites paradox can be solved while holding on to all the laws of classical logic, contrary to most attempts that reject the law of bivalence.
Given any predicate that generates a Sorites-paradox, significant use of that predicate is actually elliptical for a relational statement.
A significant token of "Bob is poor" means "Bob is poor compared to x" for some value of x.
Once a value of x is supplied, a definite cutoff line between having and not having the paradox-generating predicate is supplied, which neutralizes the inductive step.
Not all properties generate Sorites-type arguments; only properties that can be had to varying degrees generate them.
Binary properties‚Äîthose that do not admit of comparatives‚Äîdo not generate Sorites arguments.

Sorites-sentences are context-sensitive; the sentence "Bob is fast" makes a false statement if Bob is a cheetah with a top speed of 30 mph but a true statement if Bob is a turtle with a top speed of 2 mph.
Bob cannot be wealthy simpliciter; he must be wealthy compared to some standard or class.
Different tokens of "x is smart" involve comparison to different standards and thus express what are, strictly speaking, different propositions.
The term "tall" has the same meaning in "Bob is tall" as it has in "Bob is tall compared to Fred," and therefore "tall" is really elliptical for "tall compared to __."
The meaning of a predicate is intimately bound up with the number of argument places it has; predicates of different degrees ipso facto have different meanings.
Being "absolutely non-wealthy" involves just as much reference to some standard of comparison as being "comparatively non-wealthy"‚Äîit means being non-wealthy relative to every standard.
Relativization to a standard is the essence of measurement; to measure is to compare with something taken as a standard.
Degree-statements, even highly generic ones like "x is acidic to some positive degree," always presuppose some benchmark.

Libet's experiment shows that the conscious events people believe to be their decisions are not the operative intentions‚Äîconsciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
The readiness potential (RP) is obviously the proximal psychological cause of the action; therefore W (the conscious awareness) is not the intention but an awareness of the intention.
By the time W happens, the RP is almost complete; if W is part of the intention, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function.
W is not a mere epiphenomenon because consciousness of one's intentions necessarily affects subsequent thought and behavior.
The evidence suggests W is not a part of the operative intention but rather an awareness of it; W happens very late in the process.
If W were the decision responsible for the finger-movement, the graph would inflect upwards after W, not fail to inflect or inflect negatively.
W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are by their nature decisive causes, and W is not decisive.
Libet's veto experiment provides evidence that W can at least put the brakes on an already-initiated action, even if it cannot initiate actions.
Libet's experiment concerns a subset of actions‚Äîreal-time sensory-motor engagements with one's environment‚Äîbut these are actions where consciousness is presumably most heavily involved.

Standing intentions (enduring psychological structures like "my intention to create a trading platform") demonstrably cannot be constituents of consciousness; one can be conscious of them, but they are not themselves constituents of consciousness.
Libet's experiment shows that we do not have "conscious free will"; our decisions, even those governing real-time responses to the environment, are not constituents of consciousness.
The .2 second delay between intention and awareness is very possibly not mere "tape-delay" but reflects W's function as an action-monitor rather than action-instigator.
Follow-up studies using fMRI show that relevant RPs began much earlier than Libet thought, sometimes preceding W by as much as 10 seconds.
What we believe to be choices initiated in consciousness are not initiated in consciousness; they are initiated prior to any conscious awareness of them.
It is unclear how Libet's results bear on "whether we have free will," but that is because the concept of free will is unclear, not because the experimental findings are unclear.
Philosophers have responded very conservatively and defensively to Libet's findings, doing more to obfuscate than to illuminate their significance.
Indeterminism threatens freedom; determinism seems to be a prerequisite for freedom.
Thoughts that totally lacked a causal basis in a person's pre-existing psychological structures would be mere intrusions, not exercises of agency.
We only have freedom to the extent that the world, including ourselves, is deterministic.
Neuroscience does not merely show us how intentions and beliefs are physiologically implemented; it gives us counterintuitive information about them.
Libet's experimental data cannot be dismissed as margin-of-error; the subject established the time of W by coordinating it with a clock making one full rotation every 500 ms.
The distinction between proximal and distal intentions is valid, but distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions.
The actions studied in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of bona fide actions‚Äînon-automatic, non-reflexive, "freely made" actions‚Äînot quasi-reflexes.
The RP obviously causes the finger-movement; either that or it is temporally coincident with whatever the cause is‚Äîeither way, W is not the operative intention.
The idea that we "just know" we have free will is straightforwardly question-begging; free will, if it exists, is a form of causation, and what causes what is always an open empirical question.

Compatibilism says you are free even though determined, but Libet's experiment shows not so much that you are determined as that you are on the sidelines‚Äîby the time you appear, the decision has been made.
What is ominous about the Libet Experiment is not that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours‚Äîthey are yours to behold but not to make.
Libet's results are even more radical than Freud's: Freud regarded consciousness as a weak but genuine central authority; Libet shows it to be a mere spectator.
All developed philosophical positions on human agency assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices; Libet's experiment shows this to be false.
One purpose of consciousness may be to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world.
W, though not the cause of a particular intention, may implicitly green-light future similar intentions‚Äîtelling the relevant part of the mind to carry on apace.
The "illusion of free choice"‚Äîexperiencing decision-approval as decision-making‚Äîmay be a small price to pay for gains in cognitive efficiency.
Wilfred Sellars destroyed "the myth of the given" and began a revolution in epistemology, but Berkeley made essentially the same points two hundred years earlier.
The foundationalist picture holds that no empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality‚Äîa given perception can do that on its own.

Sellars is not denying that external realities are made known to us through sense-perceptions, but attacking the idea that perception does so without the cooperation of preexisting empirical knowledge.

There are two senses in which knowledge is not "given": its existence presupposes a background of empirical knowledge, and the sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge does not constitute knowledge of anything.
The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or "given"; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge.
Berkeley's argument for anti-foundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars' version.
What ultimately endows visual sensations with information regarding distances is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants.
Your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the size or distance of an object; what does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge.
One's visual experience, taken by itself and stripped of contextualization, doesn't tell one whether one is seeing a tree-size pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.
It is only "past experience" that teaches us that a particular appearance betokens a square object rather than a diamond-shaped one.
Berkeley has a definite answer to Molyneux's question: a man born blind given sight would not know from visual perceptions alone whether he was seeing a round, oval, or square object.
When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning, but your auditory experience apprises you of significance only with the help of background knowledge.
Your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence.

When a person's face reddens in a particular way indicating shame, your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the shame; background knowledge of how emotions are given bodily expression is at work.
No sensory experience by itself tells one anything; any such experience must be put in the context of background knowledge to bear any determinate message about the external world.

No sensory experience is foundational; empirical knowledge is obtained by putting current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and previously obtained empirical knowledge.

Sellars only gives one example of how sensory experiences need background knowledge (perception of color under non-standard conditions), while Berkeley's argument directly applies to virtually every perceptible property under standard conditions.

Sellars doesn't really explain how representational mental entities (perceptions) are forged out of non-representational mental entities (raw feels, qualia, sensations), but Berkeley goes to great lengths to show this.
Berkeley provides a non-metaphorical way of interpreting the metaphors that dominate contemporary anti-foundationalism (the "arc" or "web" of knowledge).
Two problems arise on Berkeley-Sellars anti-foundationalism: how any belief manages to be justified, and how anything representational arises out of what is not representational.

The problem of how perceptions arise out of non-representational sensations is more fundamental than the problem of justification, because until we have perceptions, the problem of justification doesn't arise.
Standard conditions of perception are an idealization; no conditions are really standard‚Äîif we could set up a distortion-free situation, it would not be typical.
What Sellars says about Bob's intake of color-facts in a tie-shop with unusual lighting is true of our intake of color-facts in general, and of shape-facts, size-facts, distance-facts, and so on.

A ten-foot stop-sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as a 1,000-foot stop-sign looked at from 10,000 feet away; one knows the approximate height only through background information.
In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness‚Äîto the point of having no representational content.

The appearance given off by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking object; contextual information (knowing that people don't shrink) disambiguates the visual experience.
The concept of "free will" is so unclear that difficulties in applying experimental findings to it reflect problems with the concept, not with the findings.

Philosophers seldom ask "What does the Libet experiment show?" but instead ask "What does the experiment show about free will?"‚Äîthe second question concedes too much validity to assumptions that the experiment calls into question.
Nothing is gained, and much is lost, by trying to press experimental results into the service of a pre-existing philosophical agenda.
The position that pre-W brain activity is merely an "urge" that W converts into a genuine intention is question-begging; W does not have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement.
If W happened at the very beginning or peak of the readiness potential slope, it could be a decision; but W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.
The comparison between knowledge of free will and the cogito is misconceived; the cogito registers an analytic truth whose negation is incoherent, but the assertion of free will is not trivial.
Actions studied in Libet's experiment were set up to maximize the role of consciousness; the subject was wide awake, given explicit instructions, and could push the button whenever he wanted.
The more deliberation and "rational reflection" are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious.
Philosophers have done little beyond playing skeptic with Libet's data, using standards of proof by which there would be no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer.
We stand to learn about the mind by investigating models consistent with Libet's data; we do not stand to learn by insisting that Libet "must" be wrong.
Libet's experiment represents an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for philosophy.
If it turns out that Libet's data is spurious, so be it; in the meantime, we should accept it and try to model it rather than reflexively dismissing it.
The experiments in question do not merely support but establish that consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
Consciousness may serve to approve or disapprove of decisions already made rather than to make decisions, with disapproval having a directive role for future intentions.
There is no experimental data to support the claim that Libet's results only apply to "low-level" actions that fail to engage rationality or agency.

Any episode of taking in information about the external world‚Äîany perception of height, speed, shape, or color‚Äîinvolves the cooperation of contextual or background information.KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT EMPIRICISM AND THE FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY
Empiricism is fundamentally incompatible with a scientific psychology.
There exists subpersonal thought that underlies conscious, preconscious, and repressed ideation.
Subpersonal mentation is inherently intelligent, whereas personal/conscious mentation is inherently unintelligent.
Consciousness qua consciousness is capable only of iconic (pictorial) representation.
Concepts are not constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.
Berkeley conflated images with concepts, using "idea" to refer to both.
Symbol-manipulations facilitate ratiocinative operations, but anything one can think with symbols can be thought without them.
The meaning of a complex expression cannot be directly determined by convention.
There is a fundamental distinction between object-awareness and truth-awareness (proposition-awareness).
Creatures can be merely object-aware (MOCs) or proposition-aware (PACs); all truth-aware creatures are object-aware, but not vice versa.
Desires are identical with judgments concerning what would bring pleasure or gratification.
Intentions are judgments, not desires.
Davidson's identification of intentions with one's strongest desires is false.
Higher-order desires as described by Frankfurt are often actually judgments, not desires.
Agency is identical with rationality‚Äîspecifically, applied rationality deployed in accordance with one's values.
Rational agents are fundamentally different from mere reflex machines or reagents.
The self is a rationality-constituted superstructure whose original purpose was to ensure the organism's survival but whose developed purpose is self-honing and expanding its powers.
Physiological properties are multiply realizable with respect to microphysical properties.
The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model of scientific explanation is false.
Psychological explanation works through rationalization, identifying causal mechanisms in rational motivations.
A cause can be operative even if its effect was not guaranteed‚Äîcausation can be probabilistic.
Laws need not be exceptionless regularities to have genuine explanatory value.
Macro-level properties cannot be reduced to microphysical properties.
Perception requires conceptual articulation; it is not mere sensation but articulated sensation.
Introspection is an act of conceptualization, not theoretically innocent reportage.
Husserl's phenomenological bracketing fails because one cannot strip perceptions of their conceptual articulations.
The Dennett-Churchland eliminativist position on mind is untenable.
Perceptual data is as theory-laden as psychological data.
Russell and other logicians were wrong that self-referential sentences are meaningless; such expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
The unconscious mind exists and cannot be understood in strictly empiricist terms.
Repression and rationalization are concepts inherently incompatible with empiricism.
Psychosis involves partial cognitive regression where infantile and adult thought pathologically commingle.
Neurotic people perceive external reality accurately but are blind to their own feelings.
There is a crucial distinction between access-consciousness and consciousness-proper.
Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when it becomes rule-governed through linguistic mediation.
Music transfers subpersonal intelligence to the conscious level, making otherwise imperceptible thought-processes perceptible.
Aesthetic beauty is relational‚Äîa property of relations between minds and sounds/objects, not intrinsic to sounds/objects themselves.
Sociopathy is psychological suicide: the destruction of one's value-based psychological architecture.
One can change oneself but cannot change one's self; identity is predetermined, and experience determines only how one is who one is.
Pathological insecurity and pathological grandiosity are two sides of the same coin.
Shame at being wrong is morbid and regressive, as making mistakes is inseparable from the human condition.
Folk-psychology enables rationalization of conscious states but has inherent limitations in explaining psychopathology.
Dreams involve relaxation of maturation-based inhibitions, liberating infantile mental content from the unconscious.
Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness and are knowable only to the extent they are phenomenologized.
It is viciously regressive to suppose that the self carries out the cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.
Science is not about sticking to facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures to restore continuities that observation strips away.
The empiricist's injunction to "stick to the facts" is either a triviality or an absurdity.
Perception cannot self-justify; justification for perception must come from non-empirical, analytic principles.
Rationalizations are moralizations: attempts to make the immoral seem moral.
Sociopaths do not have friends because they do not have values, and a friend is somebody one values.
Propositions are non-spatiotemporal entities that consist of properties.
Properties are non-spatiotemporal; they cannot be identified with spatiotemporal entities.
The relata of logical relations are propositions, not sentences.
Logical relations (entailment, confirmation, disconfirmation, incompatibility, neutrality) hold among propositions, not among spatiotemporal entities.
Empiricists must deny the existence of propositions because propositions are non-spatiotemporal.
Psychological propositions do not present facts as being in the same spatial coordinate system as physical propositions.
The relationship between psychology and physiology is even more remote than the relationship between physiology and microphysics.
Hume's skepticism about perception and induction follows correctly from empiricism, which should lead us to reject empiricism rather than accept skepticism.
Scientific thought is not the same as empirical thought; to the extent thought mediates between observations and beliefs, beliefs are not directly supported by observation.
Hume's analysis of causation as mere constant conjunction is false.
We perceive instances of causation directly when we perceive instances of persistence and occupancy.
Any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.
A Hume-world (a world with the same events but no causation) is incoherent because persistence itself requires causal ties.
Space-time position is constituted by causal relations; there is no non-relational way of understanding space-time position.
Events are not constituents of the external world but nominalizations of truths.
Facts and truths are distinct; truths hold in virtue of facts but are not identical with facts.
The distinction between explanatory generalizations of different disciplines lies in the concepts composing them, not in the underlying reality.
Wittgenstein's private language argument fails because the lone speaker of a private language is in no different epistemic position than the English speaker relying on memory.
Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist whose rejection of non-spatiotemporal entities like propositions and concepts follows from his empiricism.
Groups of zombies cannot collectively think; if every member of a group is a zombie, the group itself is without consciousness.
The Argument from Analogy for other minds is valid, contrary to Wittgenstein's objections.
Quine's thesis of the indeterminacy of translation is a desperate measure resulting from his empiricist commitments.
Translation between languages requires reliance on introspection-based knowledge of one's own mental states.
Thinking is not a psychological process in Wittgenstein's sense; propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
Mental imagery can be thought-constitutive, contrary to Wittgenstein's view, when understood in relation to its ratiocinative context.
The deployment of propositional attitudes in problem-solving is not constitutive of consciousness; consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under the car's hood.
Dispositionalism about mental states fails to model the data; mental states must be functioning as such even between bouts of generating consciousness.
Your belief that 1+1=2 is not identical with your dispositions to make certain judgments; it must be actively functioning to explain those dispositions.
Cognitive processes are realized by physiological processes, but psychological relations between physiological events cannot be understood in physiological terms.
Searle's view that mentality is identical with consciousness (MC) is false.
Propositional attitudes are not and cannot be constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious at most.
There is no a priori reason why propositional attitudes must be access-conscious.
Having meta-cognitive wherewithal is required to know what one's propositional attitudes are.
Russell's paradox does not establish that there are meaningful sentences that are neither true nor false; the relevant expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
The expression "the property of being the set of all sets that aren't members of themselves" picks nothing out.
Tarski's and Russell's type-theory response to the semantic paradoxes is self-defeating.
Anaphoric expressions like "itself" function as bound variables and can be eliminable in extensional contexts.
Mach was wrong to hold that molecules are useful fictions; Einstein showed their existence is required to explain Brownian motion.
Newton's public claims to be purely empirical likely misrepresented his actual methodology for rhetorical reasons.
Every person is to some degree a schizoid-affective psychopath (SAP); differences between the mentally ill and healthy are matters of degree.
To outgrow a belief or desire is not to cease to have it but for it to cease to be operational.
People are organized, non-heaps of thought; thoughts are organized both vertically (hierarchically) and horizontally (laterally).
The mind of the psychologically healthy person is stratified; psychopathology manifests when this stratification breaks down.
A delusion is not a wrong belief but a belief that is right in the wrong way‚Äîthe vehicle for a correct belief is an infantile and therefore false belief.
Pleasant affects alert us to the presence of certain structural features in music, art, and architecture; unpleasant affects alert us to their absence.
Phenomenologically consecutive mental images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint when considered in isolation from their underlying thought-processes.
The survival instinct is transferred from one's body to one's self as psychological development proceeds.
Initially the psychological superstructure exists to keep the body alive; eventually the body exists to keep the superstructure (self) alive.
To value something is to see it as conducive to the consolidation or enlargement of one's agency.
Hedonistic pleasure is value-free pleasure; accomplishment-based pleasure is not hedonistic.
The object of desire is gratification, but intentions do not aim at gratification‚Äîthey are judgments about what one must do to have a life embodying certain values.
Athletic ability is cognitive, not somatic in nature; being coordinated consists in one's mind being intelligent in governing one's body.
Moral nihilism and aesthetic nihilism are both false.
Moral nihilism and moral relativism are equivalent doctrines.
The Moore-Hume thesis that you cannot derive an "ought" from an "is" is false.
Moral truths hold in virtue of the same facts as descriptive truths; we can experience facts either as morally antiseptic or as moral truths.
Morally good acts invariably conduce to psychological, biological, or psychobiological welfare.
Emotions are beliefs, though they are not discursive beliefs; they are fundamentally egocentric in nature.
Hume's emotivism‚Äîthe view that moral ideation is non-judicative sentiment‚Äîis wrong.
There is no moral difference without a descriptive difference; the moral supervenes on the descriptive.
Moral intuitions track biological facts about welfare and harm.
One's personhood depends on having values (norms, though not necessarily moral norms).
Psychopathy is a failure to distinguish consequence of excessive rationalization; it involves a collapse of the distinction between self and other.
The acceptance of empiricism is incompatible with the very existence of any attempt to study anything.
If empiricism is correct, nothing or next to nothing can be known about either the external or internal world.
Empiricism leaves the mental as nothing but a series of disjoint ex nihilo obtrusions into an otherwise integrated world.
Paraperception is phenomenology-mediated, real-time conception‚Äîthe mode by which we perceive language, music, and art.
Categories like rock, tree, and chair are individuated by the counterfactual properties of their instances.
To be a copper bar is to have certain causal properties (conductivity, durability, malleability).
One's survival instinct comes to be transferred from one's body to one's self.
Animals are reflex machines; rational agents are not.
Something that merely reacts is sub-agential; we may call such things "reagents."
Only proposition-aware creatures can have intentions, because intentions are identical with decisions.
Deliberation is nothing other than arriving at a decision.
When an intention is not preceded by deliberation, relevant deliberations have already occurred in the past.
Aristotle and Kant were right that agency is practical rationality and decisions are conclusions of non-theoretical thought-processes.
There is no intrinsic difference between practical rationality (agency) and theoretical rationality.
Practical ratiocinations are more likely to be corrupted by prejudices and emotional factors than theoretical ones.
Phenomenology can represent a given thing only by resembling it.
Dogs are not irrational but sub-rational; irrationality is corrupted rationality and is thus a prerogative of rational beings.
Dogs' being sub-rational consists in their minds being incapable of personal thought, not thought tout court.
For ideation to be transferred from the subpersonal to the personal domain, it must be phenomenologized.
The consciousness of music is the delight we take in acquiring knowledge; it is a form of our survival instinct applied to self-expansion.
Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when governed by meta-customs that convert customs into rules.
Repressed propositional attitudes are not intrinsically different from unrepressed ones; they differ only in location within the mind.
The conscious knowledge described by Chomsky and Marr is a conceptualization of subpersonal knowledge, not a duplicate.
Subpersonal processes are not strictly physiological or purely reflexive, contrary to Searle.
Understanding a sentence requires implicit knowledge of extremely complex semantic rules that operate too quickly for conscious, discursive application.
Linguistic competence involves subpersonal mastery of rules that are not access-conscious.
There is no physiological characterization of linguistic competence; the rules are inherently semantic, not physiological.
Given obvious facts and principles, Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur.
Hume's introspections were contaminated with non-empirical ideation.
Goodman's "grue" paradox shows that any body of data can provide support for incompatible hypotheses without constraints beyond empirical observation.
There is a transcendental argument for causation: without causal ties, the genidentity of one's mind across time would be unintelligible.
The concept of complying with laws must be distinguished from the concept of being governed by them.
Everything complies with microphysical laws, but macro-level events are governed by macro-level laws implemented by varying microphysical mechanisms.
Smoking causes cancer even though less than 30% of smokers get lung cancer; causes need not operate with 100% efficacy.
Salmon's probabilistic modification of the DN model (DN*) is no better than DN itself.
Explanation can be valid even when the explanandum was less than 50% likely given the explanans.
The psychoanalyst's goal is to implant conscious duplicates of repressed beliefs, which are qualitatively identical with their repressed counterparts.
