Phenomenologically consecutive mental images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint when considered in isolation from their underlying thought-processes.
The survival instinct is transferred from one's body to one's self as psychological development proceeds.
Initially the psychological superstructure exists to keep the body alive; eventually the body exists to keep the superstructure (self) alive.
To value something is to see it as conducive to the consolidation or enlargement of one's agency.
Hedonistic pleasure is value-free pleasure; accomplishment-based pleasure is not hedonistic.
The object of desire is gratification, but intentions do not aim at gratification‚Äîthey are judgments about what one must do to have a life embodying certain values.
Athletic ability is cognitive, not somatic in nature; being coordinated consists in one's mind being intelligent in governing one's body.
Moral nihilism and aesthetic nihilism are both false.
Moral nihilism and moral relativism are equivalent doctrines.
The Moore-Hume thesis that you cannot derive an "ought" from an "is" is false.
Moral truths hold in virtue of the same facts as descriptive truths; we can experience facts either as morally antiseptic or as moral truths.
Morally good acts invariably conduce to psychological, biological, or psychobiological welfare.
Emotions are beliefs, though they are not discursive beliefs; they are fundamentally egocentric in nature.
Hume's emotivism‚Äîthe view that moral ideation is non-judicative sentiment‚Äîis wrong.
There is no moral difference without a descriptive difference; the moral supervenes on the descriptive.
Moral intuitions track biological facts about welfare and harm.
One's personhood depends on having values (norms, though not necessarily moral norms).
Psychopathy is a failure to distinguish consequence of excessive rationalization; it involves a collapse of the distinction between self and other.
The acceptance of empiricism is incompatible with the very existence of any attempt to study anything.
If empiricism is correct, nothing or next to nothing can be known about either the external or internal world.
Empiricism leaves the mental as nothing but a series of disjoint ex nihilo obtrusions into an otherwise integrated world.
Paraperception is phenomenology-mediated, real-time conception‚Äîthe mode by which we perceive language, music, and art.
Categories like rock, tree, and chair are individuated by the counterfactual properties of their instances.
To be a copper bar is to have certain causal properties (conductivity, durability, malleability).
One's survival instinct comes to be transferred from one's body to one's self.
Animals are reflex machines; rational agents are not.
Something that merely reacts is sub-agential; we may call such things "reagents."
Only proposition-aware creatures can have intentions, because intentions are identical with decisions.
Deliberation is nothing other than arriving at a decision.
When an intention is not preceded by deliberation, relevant deliberations have already occurred in the past.
Aristotle and Kant were right that agency is practical rationality and decisions are conclusions of non-theoretical thought-processes.
There is no intrinsic difference between practical rationality (agency) and theoretical rationality.
Practical ratiocinations are more likely to be corrupted by prejudices and emotional factors than theoretical ones.
Phenomenology can represent a given thing only by resembling it.
Dogs are not irrational but sub-rational; irrationality is corrupted rationality and is thus a prerogative of rational beings.
Dogs' being sub-rational consists in their minds being incapable of personal thought, not thought tout court.
For ideation to be transferred from the subpersonal to the personal domain, it must be phenomenologized.
The consciousness of music is the delight we take in acquiring knowledge; it is a form of our survival instinct applied to self-expansion.
Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when governed by meta-customs that convert customs into rules.
Repressed propositional attitudes are not intrinsically different from unrepressed ones; they differ only in location within the mind.
The conscious knowledge described by Chomsky and Marr is a conceptualization of subpersonal knowledge, not a duplicate.
Subpersonal processes are not strictly physiological or purely reflexive, contrary to Searle.
Understanding a sentence requires implicit knowledge of extremely complex semantic rules that operate too quickly for conscious, discursive application.
Linguistic competence involves subpersonal mastery of rules that are not access-conscious.
There is no physiological characterization of linguistic competence; the rules are inherently semantic, not physiological.
Given obvious facts and principles, Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur.
Hume's introspections were contaminated with non-empirical ideation.
Goodman's "grue" paradox shows that any body of data can provide support for incompatible hypotheses without constraints beyond empirical observation.
There is a transcendental argument for causation: without causal ties, the genidentity of one's mind across time would be unintelligible.
The concept of complying with laws must be distinguished from the concept of being governed by them.
Everything complies with microphysical laws, but macro-level events are governed by macro-level laws implemented by varying microphysical mechanisms.
Smoking causes cancer even though less than 30% of smokers get lung cancer; causes need not operate with 100% efficacy.
Salmon's probabilistic modification of the DN model (DN*) is no better than DN itself.
Explanation can be valid even when the explanandum was less than 50% likely given the explanans.
The psychoanalyst's goal is to implant conscious duplicates of repressed beliefs, which are qualitatively identical with their repressed counterparts.
VIEW: It is widely held that one can sometimes rationally accept propositions of the form P and not-P.
VIEW: There are necessary a posteriori truths.
VIEW: Kripke's arguments for these views appear probative only so long as one fails to distinguish between semantics and presemantics.
VIEW: The distinction between semantics and presemantics is between the literal meanings of sentences and the information on the basis of which one identifies those literal meanings.

VIEW: The failure to distinguish between semantics and presemantics underlies the popular thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes turns true sentences into false ones and vice versa.
VIEW: The thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes changes truth values has counterintuitive consequences.
VIEW: One counterintuitive consequence of the thesis is that the occurrence of 'snow' in 'it is true that snow is white' doesn't refer to snow.
VIEW: Understanding the distinction between semantics and presemantics suggests a way to develop a semantic system without the counterintuitive consequences.
VIEW: The semantic system suggested can reconcile our intuitions concerning cognitive content with some powerfully argued theses of contemporary philosophy of language.
VIEW: Some of the paper's main contentions are anticipated by Andrzej Boguslawski in his 1994 paper 'Sentential Complementation and Truth.'
VIEW: In at least some contexts, replacing a referring term with a co-referring term preserves truth-value.
VIEW: The sentence 'Hesperus is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is true.
VIEW: 'Phosphorous' and 'Hesperus' refer to the same thing.
VIEW: The sentence 'Phosphorous is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is also true.
VIEW: If a context tolerates intersubstitutions of co-referring terms, that context is 'extensional.'
VIEW: If an expression occurs in an extensional context, it occurs 'extensionally.'
VIEW: There seem to be cases where replacing a referring term with a co-referring term leads from truth to falsehood or vice versa.
VIEW: Not all contexts are extensional.
VIEW: If a context is not extensional, it is 'intensional' and the expressions occurring in it do so 'intensionally.'
VIEW: All contexts are extensional.
VIEW: The truth of 'I am tired' applies to all sentence-types with indexical or context-sensitive components.
VIEW: Most, if not all, sentence-types of natural language contain tense-markers.
VIEW: The identity of the proposition meant by a token of a sentence-type with a tense-marker depends on the time of production.
VIEW: Kaplan and Soames elaborate and defend the view that sentence-types with tense-markers depend on the time of production for their meaning.
VIEW: The function meant by a sentence-type can fail to assign a proposition to a particular token.
VIEW: An utterance about a non-existent pink elephant fails to encode a proposition.
VIEW: Strawson, Kaplan, Salmon, Soames, and others, including the author, believe that sentence-tokens typically have propositions for their literal meanings.
VIEW: Some philosophers deny that sentence-tokens typically have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings.
VIEW: Even after setting aside cases of presupposition-failure, sentence-tokens do not have truth-evaluable entities for their meanings according to some philosophers.
VIEW: Contextualists believe that sentence-tokens typically communicate propositions but require contextual facts to fill in semantic gaps.
VIEW: Recanati and Travis are proponents of contextualism or radical pragmatics.
VIEW: The meaning of 'Charles is ready' depends on knowing what Charles is ready for.
VIEW: The literal meaning of 'that is red' leaves open what has been affirmed about the object's redness.
VIEW: The standard of redness intended can vary based on the context, affecting the truth of the statement 'that is red'.
VIEW: Contextualism holds that these points about the need for context apply to all sentence-tokens, with few exceptions.
VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore provide a thorough discussion of contextualism.
VIEW: Pinker provides a brief but effective discussion of contextualism.
VIEW: Russell's Theory of Descriptions states that a sentence with the form 'the phi' has a meaning that is a quantified generalization.
VIEW: According to Russell's Theory of Descriptions, 'the king of France is bald' means a quantified generalization about the king of France being bald.
VIEW: If Russell's Theory of Descriptions is correct, 'the king of France' is not a referring term but a quantifier.
VIEW: The conception of meaning advocated by Quine, Davidson, Dummett, Chomsky, Kaplan, and Soames is not confined to one tradition.
VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore have made a strong case against contextualism.
VIEW: Pinker has also made a strong case against contextualism.
VIEW: One can hold that sentence-tokens as a rule do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings without being guilty of sheer dogmatism.
VIEW: Searle does not deny that many sentence-tokens typically have complete propositions for their literal meanings.
VIEW: Searle denies the view that for every sentence the literal meaning can be construed as the meaning it has independently of any context.
VIEW: Searle holds that the notion of literal meaning only has application relative to a set of contextual or background assumptions.
VIEW: Some tokens of 'the cat is on the mat' do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings, while others do not.
VIEW: An utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in somebody's living room will probably have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.
VIEW: The same utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in outer space may not have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.
VIEW: Searle's point is that sentence-tokens have truth-evaluable literal meanings only relative to certain background assumptions.
VIEW: Searle is not denying that sentences have literal meanings, but that literal meaning is relative to background assumptions.
VIEW: The argument in the paper is consistent with Searle's thesis.
VIEW: The question of whether or to what extent Searle's thesis is correct lies outside the scope of the present paper.
VIEW: The viewpoints of bona fide contextualists and authors with contextualist leanings have roots in the work of Wittgenstein and Austin.
VIEW: Proper names are mere labels.

VIEW: There is no difficulty accounting for the dramatic communicative differences between sentences like 'Hesperus is identical with Phosphorous' and 'Hesperus is identical with Hesperus' if proper names are mere labels.
VIEW: The differences in communication between sentences with different proper names are not due to differences in literal meaning.
VIEW: The differences in communication between sentences with different proper names are explained by how people ascertain the literal meanings of sentences.

VIEW: For any predicate phi, there is no difficulty accounting for the fact that what is communicated by 'Hesperus has phi' may differ dramatically from what is communicated by 'Phosphorous has phi' if proper names are mere labels.
VIEW: What was said about 'Hesperus' and 'Phosphorous' is true for any two co-referring proper names.
VIEW: Many apparent threats to extensionality prove to be illusory given the truth of the contentions about proper names being mere labels.
VIEW: The remaining threats to extensionality will be dealt with in subsequent sections.
VIEW: The proposition literally meant by 'Smith is a great racquetball player' is 'O is a great racquetball player' if proper names are mere labels.

VIEW: The proposition literally meant by 'Bob is a great racquetball player' is the same as the proposition meant by 'Smith is a great racquetball player' if 'Bob' and 'Smith' are mere labels for the same thing.
VIEW: Sentences 'Smith is a great racquetball player' and 'Bob is a great racquetball player' tell different things under the circumstances described.
VIEW: What is learned from 'Smith is a great racquetball player' does not entail, and is not entailed by, what is learned from 'Bob is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: It is not possible for 'Smith is a great racquetball player' and 'Bob is a great racquetball player' to tell different things if they have the same literal meaning.
VIEW: The supposed paradox that 'Smith is a great racquetball player' and 'Bob is a great racquetball player' do and do not coincide in what they tell about the world is based on a fallacy.
VIEW: What a sentence communicates to somebody isn't always confined to its literal meaning.
VIEW: There is a certain person x who uniquely has specific properties and is named 'Smith'.
VIEW: Smith is a great racquetball player.
VIEW: The content of the knowledge needed to assign the right meaning to (7) is given by (11).
VIEW: Sentence (7) communicates (11) to the speaker, despite having (8) as its literal meaning.
VIEW: What was said about (7) applies to any sentence of the form 'Smith has phi'.
VIEW: On the day in question, hearing 'Smith is also a ne chess-player' communicates a proposition similar to (12).
VIEW: The existence-claim used to access the meaning of (7) changes over time.
VIEW: Two days after first seeing Smith, the existence-claim for the utterance 'Smith has decided to become a professional chess-player' is not (13) but (14).
VIEW: There are other reasons why the information used to access the literal meaning of (7) must change over time.
VIEW: What was said about (7) applies to (9).
VIEW: Hearing the noise 'Bob' and knowing what it refers to are different.
VIEW: To fix 'Bob' to the right person, background knowledge must be exploited.
VIEW: The relevant background knowledge for 'Bob' is given by a proposition similar to (15).
VIEW: At the level of semantics, 'Bob' merely labels an individual x without describing it.
VIEW: The information through which the speaker learns that 'Bob' labels x does describe x.
VIEW: Just after shaking hands with Bob, hearing 'Bob is a great racquetball player' communicates a proposition similar to (16).
VIEW: Any sentence of the form 'Bob has phi' would communicate a proposition similar to (17) under the described circumstances.
VIEW: Sentences (7) and (9) have entirely different cognitive values under the described circumstances.
VIEW: Sentence (7) communicates (11), while sentence (9) communicates (16).
VIEW: Propositions (11) and (16) are completely different and do not entail each other.
VIEW: The expression 'that snow is white' is neither true nor false.
VIEW: The expression 'that snow is white' refers to the proposition semantically encoded in 'snow is white'.
VIEW: The expression 'that Smith is a great racquetball player' refers to the proposition semantically encoded in 'Smith is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: The expression 'that Bob is a great racquetball player' refers to the proposition semantically encoded in 'Bob is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: Proper names are mere labels.
VIEW: The proposition referred to by both 'that Smith is a great racquetball player' and 'that Bob is a great racquetball player' is 'That O is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: The sentence 'Fred believes that Bob is a great racquetball player' attributes the property of being believed by Fred to the proposition 'That O is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: The sentence 'Fred believes that Smith is a great racquetball player' attributes the property of being believed by Fred to the proposition 'That O is a great racquetball player'.
VIEW: The sentences 'Fred believes that Bob is a great racquetball player' and 'Fred believes that Smith is a great racquetball player' semantically encode the same proposition.
VIEW: The sentences 'Fred believes that Bob is a great racquetball player' and 'Fred believes that Smith is a great racquetball player' may differ in truth-value in terms of what they communicate.
VIEW: Semantically, 'Bob' is a name.
VIEW: Under certain circumstances, sentences containing 'Bob' communicate propositions of the form 'there is a person x such that x uniquely has thus and such characteristics and 'Bob' is x's name'.
VIEW: Under certain circumstances, 'Bob' acts as a certain kind of existential quantifier.
VIEW: The quantifier 'Bob' can be given either wide-scope or narrow-scope with respect to 'Fred believes'.
VIEW: The sentence 'Fred believes that Bob is a great racquetball player' is ambiguous between two propositions regarding the scope of the quantifier 'Bob'.
VIEW: The expression 'for some king of France x, x is a king of France and such that, for any king of France y, y=x' is a quantifier.
VIEW: The expression 'for any object king of France z, z is bald' is a quantifier.
VIEW: Definite descriptions are quantifiers or quantifier-like, according to Russell's theory.
VIEW: If Russell's theory is correct, there is much to be said for the view that definite descriptions are quantifiers.
VIEW: The concept of indirect-reference will be discussed in Part III.
VIEW: If definite descriptions are not referring terms, the difference in truth-value between examples (5) and (6) is irrelevant to the question of extensionality.
VIEW: It cannot be taken for granted that definite descriptions are not referring terms.

VIEW: To establish extensionality, one must establish either that definite descriptions are not referring terms or that intersubstituting co-referring definite descriptions does not change truth-value.
VIEW: If contention (B) is correct, then the question of whether contention (A) is correct becomes irrelevant to the question of whether extensionality is correct.
VIEW: The author will argue for contention (B).
VIEW: Even if (5) and (6) have the same literal meaning, there is no difficulty accounting for the fact that they may communicate propositions with different truth-values.
VIEW: There are two kinds of referring terms: those that refer directly and those that refer indirectly.
VIEW: According to Kaplan, when addressing Fred with 'you are tall', the literal meaning is the singular proposition that Fred is tall.
VIEW: Kaplan's position generalized states that a token of an indexical expression that refers to an object O has a literal meaning that includes O itself as a constituent.
VIEW: When using 'you' in a sentence, the proposition encoded includes the person being addressed as a constituent, not a concept under which they fall.
VIEW: The concept 'person to whom I am speaking' does not enter into the proposition meant by the utterance of 'you'.
VIEW: The utterance of 'you' is directly referential.
VIEW: The concept 'person to whom I am speaking' plays an important semantic role but does not itself enter into the proposition.
VIEW: When pointing to a car and saying 'that must have cost a fortune', the literal meaning is that the car must have cost a fortune.
VIEW: The concept 'ostended object' is not part of the literal meaning of the utterance about the car.
VIEW: If definite descriptions are directly referential, intersubstituting them never changes the truth-value of what is literally meant by sentences.
VIEW: The term 'direct referentialism' refers to the position that definite descriptions are devices of direct reference.
VIEW: The term 'Russellianism' refers to the position that definite descriptions are not referring terms and are instead quantifiers or quantifier-like expressions as described by Russell.
VIEW: Direct referentialists agree almost entirely with Russellians.
VIEW: Both Russellians and direct referentialists agree that 'the phi' is true if and only if something x uniquely has phi and x satisfies the rest of the sentence.
VIEW: Russellians and direct referentialists disagree about the semantics of 'the phi'.
VIEW: For Russellians, 'the phi' means there is exactly one object O that has phi and O satisfies the rest of the sentence.
VIEW: For direct referentialists, if there is exactly one object O that has phi, then 'the phi' means O satisfies the rest of the sentence.
VIEW: If nothing uniquely has phi, then for direct referentialists, 'the phi' does not bear any proposition and is neither true nor false.
VIEW: According to the direct referentialist, 'the inventor of bifocals snored' does not encode any proposition if nobody uniquely invented bifocals.
VIEW: If exactly one person O invented bifocals, then for the direct referentialist, 'the inventor of bifocals snored' means O snored.
VIEW: Given that Benjamin Franklin uniquely invented bifocals, the direct referentialist says that 'the inventor of bifocals snored' encodes the proposition that Benjamin Franklin snored.
VIEW: According to the Russellian, the proposition encoded in 'the inventor of bifocals snored' is equivalent to 'exactly one object x invented bifocals; moreover, x snored'.
VIEW: The direct-referentialist's position and the Russellian's position differ significantly because the propositions they encode do not entail each other.

VIEW: A consequence of the direct-referentialist's position is that 'Fred believes that the inventor of bifocals snored' encodes the proposition 'Fred believes that O snored' for some object O identical with Benjamin Franklin.
VIEW: For the direct referentialist, 'Fred believes that the first postmaster general snored' also has the meaning 'Fred believes that O snored'.

VIEW: Another consequence of the direct-referentialist's position is that 'Little Timmy believes that the whole number that comes immediately after one is less than three' has the literal meaning 'Little Timmy believes that O is one less than three' for some O identical with the number two.

VIEW: For the direct referentialist, 'Little Timmy believes that the number n such that n is a unique even prime if arithmetic is incomplete and is otherwise a unique positive square root of 71 is less than three' also has the meaning 'Little Timmy believes that O is one less than three'.
VIEW: If direct referentialism is correct, then sentences (5) and (6) coincide in respect of literal meaning and truth-value, as do sentences (36) and (38).
VIEW: There is a glaring difference in cognitive value between sentences (36) and (38) and also between sentences (5) and (6).
VIEW: An immediate consequence of the direct-referentialist's position is that anyone who understands (32) knows that it isn't either true or false.
VIEW: An immediate consequence of the direct-referentialist's position is that (32) isn't true unless exactly one object x invented bifocals and x snored.
VIEW: The italicized proposition is identical with (35).
VIEW: An immediate consequence of the direct-referentialist's position is that an utterance of (32) will communicate (35).
VIEW: If the direct referentialist were right, then the semantic rule for (32) would be (NR).
VIEW: (NR) is not the right semantic rule.
VIEW: What 'the inventor of bifocals' refers to is a function of who invented bifocals.
VIEW: If Smith invented bifocals, then 'the inventor of bifocals' refers to Smith.
VIEW: If Jones invented bifocals, then 'the inventor of bifocals' refers to Jones.

VIEW: If definite descriptions are devices of reference, then the semantic rule for 'the inventor of bifocals' is that if somebody O uniquely invented bifocals, then 'the inventor of bifocals' refers to O.

VIEW: If definite descriptions are devices of direct reference, then the semantic rule for 'the inventor of bifocals' is that if somebody O uniquely invented bifocals, then 'the inventor of bifocals' refers directly to O.
VIEW: If definite descriptions are devices of direct reference, then the semantic rule for 'the inventor of bifocals snored' will be (RF).
VIEW: If the direct referentialist is right, a token of (32) will communicate (35).
VIEW: When people understand sentences, they do so on the basis of a knowledge of the relevant semantic rules.
VIEW: It is not an unreasonable assumption that people understand sentences based on knowledge of semantic rules.
VIEW: People know what the sentence 'if there's an albatross in Greenland, then either coal is purple or owls speak Portuguese' means even if they have never heard it before.
VIEW: The most plausible way to explain understanding of the sentence about albatrosses, coal, and owls is that people know the relevant semantic rules.
VIEW: Chomsky provides powerful arguments for the view that people understand sentences based on knowledge of semantic rules.
VIEW: If the direct-referentialist's position is correct, what is communicated by (40) will be identical or at least equivalent with (41).
VIEW: The direct referentialist holds that for some object O, the bare singular proposition (33) is the literal meaning of (40).
VIEW: Exactly one thing x uniquely invented bifocals, and exactly one thing y was a unique first postmaster general, and x=y.
VIEW: Direct referentialism can account for the fact that (42) is non-trivial in terms of what it communicates.
VIEW: According to Russell's theory, either (43) itself, or some proposition logically equivalent with (43), is what is meant by (42).
VIEW: Direct referentialism has many of the virtues that are ascribed to the Theory of Descriptions.
VIEW: Direct referentialism explains why (5) and (6) differ in respect of cognitive value.
VIEW: Direct referentialism explains why (42) is non-trivial.
VIEW: Direct referentialism accounts for the fact that (5) is ambiguous between wide-scope and narrow-scope readings in terms of what utterances of it communicate.

VIEW: The Theory of Descriptions cannot be preferred to referentialism on the grounds that the latter is inconsistent with the facts concerning what is communicated by sentences containing definite descriptions.
VIEW: Direct referentialism, if correct, is no threat to extensionality.
VIEW: If direct referentialism is correct, (5) and (6) coincide in respect of literal meaning and truth-value, as do (36) and (38).
VIEW: The view that (5) and (6) must differ in respect of literal meaning due to their differences in what they communicate is misguided.
VIEW: The direct-referentialist's view is that the sense of a definite description doesn't make it into the proposition meant by the sentence in which that definite description occurs.
VIEW: Definite descriptions are quantifiers according to one view.
VIEW: Substitution-failures involving definite descriptions don't threaten extensionality if we focus only on the direct-referentialist and quantifier views.
VIEW: There is a third possibility to consider, that definite descriptions are devices of indirect reference, which was Frege's view.
VIEW: The indirect referentialist says that 'the inventor of bifocals' refers to Benjamin Franklin.
VIEW: The indirect referentialist rejects Russell's Theory of Descriptions.
VIEW: The proposition literally meant by (32) does not have Benjamin Franklin himself as a constituent but has a concept under which Benjamin Franklin uniquely falls.

VIEW: If a sentence S has the form '...the inventor of bifocals...', then S encodes a proposition that has as a constituent a concept C such that the referent of 'the inventor of bifocals' satisfies C.
VIEW: If a sentence S has the form '...the phi...', then S encodes a proposition that has as a constituent a concept C such that the referent of 'the phi' satisfies C.
VIEW: P is true in world w if O snored
VIEW: P is true if (33) is true
VIEW: P and (33) could be identical
VIEW: The proposition meant by (44) is true if Benjamin Franklin snored
VIEW: There is an object O such that O is Benjamin Franklin
VIEW: The proposition meant by any sentence S with 'Benjamin Franklin' is true if O has property x
VIEW: 'Benjamin Franklin' refers to Benjamin Franklin
VIEW: 'Benjamin Franklin' directly refers to Benjamin Franklin
VIEW: The proposition meant by (32) is true in many worlds where (33) is false if the indirect referentialist is right
VIEW: The proposition meant by (32) is false in many worlds where (33) is true if the indirect referentialist is right
VIEW: PIR is true in exactly the same worlds as PTD
VIEW: PIR being true in the same worlds as PTD does not show they are identical
VIEW: PIR being true in the same worlds as PTD suggests PIR is a quantified generalization
VIEW: There are semantic similarities between indirect reference and quantification
VIEW: There are no significant semantic differences between indirect reference and quantification
VIEW: There are semantic differences between expressions that directly refer and those that refer indirectly
VIEW: PIR is not significantly different from PTD from a proof-theoretic standpoint
VIEW: PTD and PIR entail and are entailed by the same propositions
VIEW: PTD and PIR are equivalent
VIEW: PTD and PIR coincide in respect of their fine-grained inferential properties
VIEW: A quantifier is an expression that answers a question of the form 'how many phi's are psi's?'
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, (32) is logically equivalent to the proposition that exactly one thing invented bifocals and any such thing is tall
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, (32) answers the question 'how many things are bifocal-inventors?'
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, (32) answers the question 'how many bifocal-inventors snored?'
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, 'the inventor of bifocals' is quantifier-like in some important respects
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, the semantics of 'the inventor of bifocals' is extremely similar to the semantics that the Russellian ascribes to it
VIEW: If the indirect referentialist is right, 'the inventor of bifocals' is semantically very different from any instance of an expression that clearly refers to Benjamin Franklin
VIEW: Clear-cut cases of reference have significant similarities with cases of indirect reference

VIEW: Similarities between clear-cut cases of reference and clear-cut cases of quantification give no more weight to the position that definite descriptions are devices of reference than they do to the position that they are quantifiers
VIEW: A complete sentence can be formed by replacing the variable 'x' in 'x snored' with either 'Benjamin Franklin' or 'the inventor of bifocals'
VIEW: The fact that a well-formed sentence results when 'Benjamin Franklin' replaces the variable is to be understood in terms of the semantics of 'Benjamin Franklin'
VIEW: The semantic job of 'Benjamin Franklin' is to pick out some entity or other
VIEW: The exact identity of the entity picked out by 'Benjamin Franklin' is irrelevant in this context
VIEW: Replacing the variable with a quantifier like 'some person' results in a meaningful sentence
VIEW: The expression 'and snores' is meaningless when taken as a complete utterance
VIEW: The reason 'and snores' is meaningless is that 'and' doesn't combine with 'snores' in the right way
VIEW: 'The inventor of bifocals' and 'Benjamin Franklin' have similar combinatorial-syntactic properties
VIEW: The reason 'the inventor of bifocals snored' and 'Benjamin Franklin snored' are meaningful is not that they have similar semantic properties
VIEW: 'Some man' has the right syntactic properties to form a meaningful sentence like 'some man snored'
VIEW: 'Some man' is semantically very different from any singular term
VIEW: If E occurs in S, then S contains a sentence that answers a question of the form 'how many phi's are psi's?'
VIEW: The definition of a quantifier, though an improvement on McCawley's, still falls short
VIEW: The reason the definition falls short is that it deals only with sentences in the indicative mood
VIEW: The sentence 'are some people are happy?' doesn't answer any question of the form 'how many phi's are psi's?'
VIEW: The sentence 'are some people are happy?' doesn't answer any question because it is itself a question
VIEW: The proposition encoded in the sentence 'are some people are happy?' does answer a question of the form 'how many phi's are psi's?'
VIEW: The proposition encoded in the sentence 'are some people are happy?' is that some people are happy
VIEW: A quantifier is an expression E such that, if a sentence S contains E, S encodes a proposition that answers a question of the form 'how many phi's are psi's?'
VIEW: The similarities between 'the inventor of bifocals' and other expressions are syntactic, not semantic, in nature
VIEW: Given that reference is a semantic function, the syntactic similarities do not support the contention that 'the inventor of bifocals' is anything other than a quantifier
VIEW: Indirect referentialism is committed to an incoherent semantic view
VIEW: Indirect reference is identical with Russellian quantification
VIEW: Indirect referentialism is merely a confused version of Russellianism

Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.
The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.
When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.
Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.
The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.
Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.
A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.
Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.
Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.
Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.
Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.
Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.
A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.
Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.
To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.
A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.
Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.
There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.
Constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations among symbols.
The thought "that is a sphere" is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought "that is a closed figure of uniform curvature."
Conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing; a single semantic analysis may correspond to multiple conceptual analyses.
Color concepts are not mutually definable, yet they are constitutively interconnected; one cannot grasp one color without grasping others.
Any concept has constitutive connections to other concepts; conceptual atomism is false.
One cannot represent a single property to oneself without being able to represent other properties; representational capacities come in networks.
To grasp a specific shade of color, one must be able to distinguish it from other colors and thus grasp multiple colors.
If a creature could represent only one shade of color, its concept of that shade would collapse into a concept of color in general.
Properties are individuated by their relations to other properties; grasping a property requires grasping its place in a space of properties.
Degree properties like "weighing 1000 lbs" obviously require grasping related properties; this point generalizes to all properties.
A language must comprise basic expressions; otherwise knowledge of any expression would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon.
Proper names are not definite descriptions, as Kripke decisively showed.
What we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean; semantic externalism is correct.
Twin Earth cases show that the meanings of natural kind terms are not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
Content internalism is compatible with semantic externalism; linguistic meaning and cognitive content are distinct.
Reference-fixing should be distinguished from meaning-giving; this distinction dissolves many puzzles about concepts.
To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes that thing.
Knowledge of an existential proposition that uniquely describes x suffices for the ability to think about x.
Conception is sustained by knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, which may include indexical elements.
Recognition consists in seeing that one object satisfies two existence claims previously thought to be satisfied by different objects.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on propositional content; intentionalism is false.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on non-propositional representational content either.
Intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations.
A tickle or twinge is too simple and homogeneous to bear fine-grained propositions about anatomical structures.
Creatures can experience phenomenal contents like woozy feelings without possessing vast networks of representational capacities.
If intentionalism were true, a twinge would deliver vastly more information than such sensations actually deliver.
Phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content‚Äînot identical with or supervenient on it.
Even restricted intentionalism (within sensory modalities) collapses into non-intentionalism upon examination.
There is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content.
Different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content.
The relationship between phenomenal contents and their physical causes is like a "rule of projection" that could be different.
The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because there is no purely morphological characterization of syntax.
There is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth; adequate characterizations must be partially semantic.
The only way to sensitize a thing to logical form is to sensitize it to semantics.
Turing machines do not compute in the relevant sense because they do not respond to semantics.
Adding numbers is never a purely mechanical, cognition-free operation even when done by the "quick and dirty" method.
A representationally innocent entity generating patterns of shapes does not constitute genuine computation.
Computing involves being sensitive to logical form, and logical form is buried in semantics.
The Ramsey-Lewis sentence method for defining theoretical terms is useless because functionalism cannot be articulated without vicious circularity.
Functionalism fails because it cannot non-circularly specify the mental states in terms of which functional roles are defined.
Content externalism strips mental content of causal efficacy; if externalism is true, content cannot explain behavior.
Program causes (as defined by Jackson and Pettit) do not rescue content externalism from the causal impotence objection.
Mental causation requires that mental content be causally relevant in a way externalism cannot accommodate.
Davidson's anomalous monism leads to epiphenomenalism about the mental.
Jerry Fodor's computationalism is pseudo-computationalism because he cannot adequately account for how syntax tracks semantics.
Fodor's main argument for conceptual atomism fails because constitutive connections are not containment relations.
Fodor confuses the claim that concepts are not decomposable with the claim that concepts lack constitutive connections to others.
Non-atomism does not require inferential role semantics (IRS); the inference from one to the other is fallacious.
Inferential role semantics faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication becomes impossible.
Inferential role semantics leads to an untenable holism where no two people can grasp the same proposition.
The bundle theory of personal identity is defensible when properly understood.
Propositions are sets of properties; truth is the instantiation of all members of that set.
A proposition like "Smith punches Jones" is a set containing properties corresponding to Smith, Jones, and the punching relation.
For a proposition to be true is for all of its component properties to be instantiated.
Propositions have decompositional structure; they are not merely specified by truth-conditions.
Analytically equivalent propositions can convey very different information.
Analytic propositions do typically convey information, contrary to Lewis's model.
Hempel's paradox is solved by recognizing that accidental generalizations do not receive support from their instances.
Only principled (nomic) generalizations receive confirmational support from their instances.
"If x is heated metal, x expands" and "If x isn't expanding, x isn't heated metal" are not confirmationally equivalent when read nomically.
Negative facts (like not being heated metal) are not fit to stand in nomic relations because they are not events or constituted by events.
A thing's not having a property is not nomically connected to anything, unlike a thing's having a property.
Inductions by enumeration are actually crypto-inferences to the best explanation.
Formal truth is truth by virtue of being an instance of a sentence-schema all of whose instances are true.
Formal truth is not identical with syntactic truth; there is no purely morphological characterization of logical form.
The equation of formal truth with syntactic truth is viciously circular.
Not all logical truths are formal truths; logic cannot be identified with the study of formal truth.
The most fundamental truths of logic must consist of non-formal, analytic truths.
The linguistic theory of logical truth (that logical truths are true by convention) is false.
Logical truths are not true merely in virtue of the meanings of words or linguistic conventions.
Conceivability sometimes entails possibility, providing a neo-Cartesian argument for dualism.
If mental properties are not identical with physical properties, and identity is necessary, then dualism follows.
Time travel is an incoherent concept.
Probabilistic causation is a genuine form of causation distinct from deterministic causation.
Simulated thought is not actual thought; genuine mental processes cannot be simulated by non-mental processes.
Davidson's views on rationality embody fundamental misconceptions.
Foundationalism about knowledge is compatible with non-atomism about concepts.
Intentionalism (the view that phenomenal properties are representational properties) fails both in restricted and unrestricted forms.
The veil of perception problem is exacerbated by externalism, not solved by it.
Representationalism about perception faces serious objections from the nature of phenomenal experience.
Understanding a sentence requires knowing multiple existence claims and their connections.
Identification is relative to background knowledge; being able to identify an object means connecting it to background knowledge.
A parrot cannot really say "it's getting hotter" because it lacks grasp of concepts and semantic rules.
For a sentence to have meaning for a speaker, it must have internal structure connected to concepts.
The meaning of complex sentences is a resultant, not a mere heaping together, of component meanings.
The word "fire" in isolation has the same semantics as in complex sentences; meaning operates through concepts uniformly.
Sense perceptions have existential content; the content of a perception is given by some bit of existential information.
Introspection, while limited, is reasonably reliable for apprehending the nature of phenomenal contents.
If phenomenal contents deliver information, our conscious minds must retrieve this information, suggesting we know our phenomenal contents well.
Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.
The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.
When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.
Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.
The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.
Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.
A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.
Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.
Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.
Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.
Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.
Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.
A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.
Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.
To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.
A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.
Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.
There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.

Kant's argument for synthetic a priori truths is spurious, but his important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct when de-psychologized.
Kant's premises actually entail the opposite of his thesis: there are virtually no a priori truths, making Kant more opposed to a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.
Kant confuses two different epistemological roles of mental imagery: as a vehicle for conceptual analysis and as an object of empirical study.
Kant's reasoning must be de-psychologized‚Äîhis statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic.
Conceptual necessity is non-psychological necessity that holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the platonic sense.
The proposition "triangles have three sides" would still be true even if there were no sentient beings.
Representational necessity is a different category where propositions are necessarily true because of facts about our minds.
Wittgenstein's regress argument shows that grasping a norm is not a cognitive affair in the traditional sense of having an inner representation.
Grasping a norm consists in having certain dispositions, not in possessing some mental icon corresponding to that norm.
Knowing-how is not cognitive in the sense of involving a grasp of propositions; it is a kind of competence or sensitivity.
For Wittgenstein, to know what a sentence means is to know how to use it, which is to be coordinated with other people's usage.
Knowledge-how does ultimately reduce to knowledge-that; knowing how to do something consists in internally representing rules.
Brandom's account of how individuals acquire intentionality is circular: one cannot give and ask for reasons without first grasping reasons.
Locke, Kant, and classical philosophers were right that speaking is a kind of externalized thinking, not vice versa.
The idea that thinking is internalized speaking (Wittgenstein, Brandom) is false.
Given a group of creatures oblivious to norms, no amount of interaction will make any of them aware of norms.
The "buck cannot be passed onto society": a society of normless individuals will itself be normless.
A proposition is a special kind of norm: a standard against which reality is compared.
To expect dinner tomorrow, unlike expecting dinner now, requires de dicto awareness and grasp of concepts.
Ordinary stimuli have no internal structure, but sentences are articulate‚Äîtheir parts stand in significant relations.
Through Pavlovian training you can make a dog react to stimuli, but you cannot make it understand compound sentences.
Understanding "if there's smoke, there's fire" requires grasping the concepts of smoke and fire, not just particular instances.
Identity holds necessarily: if A can be distinct from B, then A must be distinct from B.
Logical possibility sometimes indicates actual possibility, but not always‚Äîthe relevant difference involves object-dependent vs. object-independent concepts.
Whenever there is a disparity between logical and metaphysical possibility, it is underwritten by facts about object-dependent concepts.
Necessities underwritten wholly by object-independent concepts have logical possibility coinciding with metaphysical possibility.
Object-dependent concepts have actual spatiotemporal objects as constituents; object-independent concepts do not.
To grasp an object-involving proposition, one must have causal liaisons to the object; purely existential propositions can be grasped without such liaisons.
A brain in a vat could grasp purely existential propositions but not object-involving propositions about spatiotemporal objects.
There is no purely morphological characterization of syntax; syntax is buried in semantics.
Any expression could mean anything; given any entity, there is some language in which "172" denotes that entity.
There can be no algorithm deciding truth-value wholly on the basis of shape; truth-value requires morphology plus semantic background.
An algorithm is given by a conditional proposition: if such and such semantic system holds, then there is a morphological characterization of truth.
To apply an algorithm involves recognizing the truth of a multiply conditional proposition about semantics and shapes.
The manipulation of shapes is at most a causal consequence of actual computation‚Äîalmost an epiphenomenon.
Even if there are algorithms for various domains, thought in those domains cannot be "mechanized."
There are two components to applying an algorithm: recognition of an operative semantic system (not mechanical) and patterns of shapes (can be mechanical).
Inference requires recognition that premises stand in a bearing relation (entailment or probabilification) to the conclusion.
To have a rational thought-process, symbols must follow one another in a way that embodies awareness of bearing-relations among them.
A computer's symbols follow one another in the right order, but this doesn't involve recognition of bearing relations‚Äîso computers don't really think.
A computation is a purely formal, syntax-driven inference where consideration of semantics plays no part.
Fodor's "solution" to how physics-driven brain activity can be logic-consistent involves a massive confusion.
The "tracking problem"‚Äîhow purely descriptive brain activity embodies sensitivity to prescriptive norms‚Äîis not solved by CTM.
Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands its expressions; it isn't by being understood that Mentalese tokens facilitate thought.
Mentalese, if it existed, would differ radically from real languages because its expressions need not be understood to function.
The very concept of a "language of thought" is incoherent because languages require understanding to function.
Brains are governed entirely by the laws of physics, which are purely descriptive, not prescriptive.
Our mental lives are entirely realized by brain activity, yet our mental activity conforms to canons of good reasoning.
Laws of physics are not laws of rationality, so laws of rationality seemingly play no part in our thinking‚Äîyet clearly they do.
What we think largely determines what our expressions mean, but there is also an important non-psychological dimension to meaning.
Given psychological and behavioral indistinguishability, it does not follow that utterances have the same meanings.
Twin Earth cases show that two utterances can differ in meaning despite arising from psychologically identical states.
The word "water" refers to H2O even for speakers in the 1600s who knew nothing of chemistry.
If a substance were discovered to be XYZ rather than H2O, chemists would say it is extremely water-like, not that water is sometimes XYZ.
Semantic externalism is true: meaning is not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
Content internalism is also true: what we are thinking is wholly determined by our internal states.
The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving dissolves the apparent tension between externalism about meaning and internalism about content.
The representational content of visual perception can be put into words and embodied in propositions.
All representational content is essentially propositional; there is no genuinely non-propositional representational content.
Functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong: you stop because you see a stop-sign, not vice versa.
For functionalism, a perception has its content in virtue of causing certain behavior‚Äîbut content is what causes behavior.
If x exists in virtue of y's existing, then x cannot cause y to exist; so functionalism makes content causally inert.
Functionalism says you see a growling dog because you flee, but obviously you flee because you see a growling dog.
Whenever one adds a referring term to one's lexicon, it involves knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent.
The semantics of a name are not existential-descriptive, but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.
Names are just labels semantically, but one learns which thing a name labels through existential-descriptive claims.
To avoid running afoul of Kripke's points, we must give operators like "refers to" narrow scope relative to descriptive content.
Recognition of an individual consists in seeing that one thing uniquely satisfies each of two existence claims.
Conception is sustained by knowledge of a series of interlocking existence claims; any given claim may be dropped and replaced.
At any juncture of having a conception of a thing, that conception involves knowledge of an existence claim.
The cognitive difference between "Hesperus is lovely" and "Phosphorous is lovely" is explained by different existence claims.
Intentionalism is guilty of what Sellars called "the myth of the given."
Visual sensations do not by themselves tell you what color an object is; background knowledge about environmental conditions is required.
Sensations coupled with background knowledge about conditions of perception tell you what properties objects have.
What makes a bit of phenomenal content have a given representational content is precisely the addition of background knowledge.
If Sellars is right about the myth of the given, then intentionalism must be completely wrong.
Perceivable properties require contextualizing information to be represented; they are not intrinsically associated with phenomenal contents.
Tickles and twinges bear only highly generic messages like "disturbance of some kind in such and such part of my body."
Sensations do not constitute high-resolution apprehensions of bodily conditions; they are fairly opaque and uninformative.
Intentionalism demands that sensations be very non-opaque and high-resolution, which they plainly are not.
Even if sensations bore non-propositional information, they still would not bear enough information to vindicate intentionalism.
Non-propositional content, if it exists, presupposes the same vast networks of representational capacities as propositional content.
The ability to have any kind of representation presupposes the ability to represent things as having properties.
A morphinated feeling of euphoria has no felt bodily location‚Äîno spatial representations seem involved.
Some phenomenal contents are "generalized" feelings not felt in any particular body part.
Knowing what is distinctive about a color involves knowing how it differs from other colors.
Grasping the specific character of a property involves grasping what distinguishes it from other properties.
One can grasp a specific shape-property only if one has a grasp of a whole "space" of shape properties.
Direct reference theory does not show that names express no concepts whatsoever.
Freud held that thoughts must be clothed in words to become conscious‚Äîa view with some merit.
Hume's ethical anti-realism is connected to his view that emotions are incapable of being true or false.
Emotions can be justified or unjustified, rational or irrational‚Äîproperties that only beliefs can have.
People try to justify their emotions, both negative and positive, suggesting emotions answer to rational standards.
When someone narcotizes an irrational emotion, this presupposes that emotions can be evaluated as rational or irrational.
Moral statements embody emotions; since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral realism follows.
Speech-act semantics and tractarian semantics are not really opposed on the relation between sentences and propositions.
If a sentence bears a proposition, then ipso facto it enables one to express the corresponding belief.
Hempel's paradox arises only if we conflate accidental generalizations with principled (nomic) generalizations.
Accidental generalizations like "all heated metal expands" read as mere de facto concomitances don't receive support from instances.
Only nomic generalizations‚Äîthose alleging causal or lawlike connections‚Äîreceive confirmational support from their instances.
Nomic relations hold only among spatiotemporal entities; negative facts like "not being heated metal" are not spatiotemporal.
A thing's not having a property is like not destroying Jupiter‚Äîit is not an event and doesn't stand in nomic relations.
The operator "there is a nomic connection between..." doesn't permit intersubstitution of logically equivalent sentences.
Logically equivalent sentences can be truth-preservingly intersubstituted in some contexts but not in contexts governed by nomic operators.
Given that "P iff P" is formally true, the statement "all statements of the form P iff P are formally true" is itself not formal.
It is always on the basis of knowledge of non-formal truths that we know a given truth to be formal.
It is an empirical fact that logical connectives have the syntactic and semantic properties they have.
It is non-empirically true that, given their properties, certain connectives are truth-functional‚Äîthis is analytic but non-formal.
Those non-formal, analytic truths are themselves part of logic and constitute its essence more than formal truths do.
Formal logic is to pure logic as engineering is to physics‚Äîformal logic is applied logic.
Logicians who dedicate themselves exclusively to formal work are applied logicians, not logicians in the truest sense.
Bradley's Logic and Mill's Treatise on Logic, despite containing no formal reasoning, are genuine works of logic.
A sentence is formally true if it is an instance of an open-sentence true for all values of its free variables.
A proposition is a property of a world; for a proposition to be true is for that property to be instantiated.
Truth can be identified with instantiatedness: a proposition is true exactly if that property is instantiated in the actual world.
Lewis's identification of propositions with properties of worlds is informative but viciously circular if taken as an analysis.
Propositions have decompositional structure that mere sets of worlds or functions from worlds to truth-values do not capture.
Analytic propositions do convey information, contrary to views that make them disappear as uninformative.
A true proposition is always true in virtue of something about the world‚Äîmass-energy distribution, ripples in the quantum.
The truth of "Plato punched Socrates" supervenes on facts about atomic movements describable without mentioning Plato or Socrates.
The property of having the right "rippling" of mass-energy is more basic than the proposition it makes true.
There is no circularity in analyzing propositions in terms of properties of worlds when those properties are more basic.
Different propositions can share constituents: "Smith punches Jones" and "Plato punches Jones" share the "punches Jones" component.
A proposition has components corresponding to incomplete properties like "x punches Jones" and "Smith punches x."
Frege's analysis that propositions are built from relations and functions captures the structure of propositions correctly.
A proposition is a set of properties; it is true when all its members are instantiated.
Each discrete constituent of a proposition corresponds to one property in the set that constitutes it.
Fodor's argument for atomism fails because constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations.
Fodor confuses the claim that concepts resist decomposition with the claim that they lack constitutive connections.
One's pink-concept is not composed of other color-concepts, yet one cannot have it without having other color-concepts.
Color-symbols are not mutually definable; color concepts are not decomposable into other color concepts.
If color concepts literally contained other color concepts, any color thought would consist of infinitely many color thoughts‚Äîabsurd.
Any attempt to block the infinite regress through looping definitions makes concept-possession presuppose itself.
One's concept of 1,143 presupposes concepts of 1,142, 1,141, etc., but 1,143-thoughts are not cobbled together from these.
Fodor is right that most concepts resist decomposition, but wrong that this means they lack constitutive connections.
Inferential role semantics makes it impossible for two people to grasp the same proposition.
For IRS, differences in inferential role mean differences in content; but no two cognitive states have identical inferential roles.
IRS faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication of concepts becomes impossible.
If IRS is right, wrong applications of a concept collapse into correct applications of some other concept‚Äîbut plainly this is false.
The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving saves non-atomism from the objections Fodor raises.
To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes (uniquely individuates) that thing.
Knowledge of a proposition describing x suffices for ability to think about x‚Äîit qualifies as a concept of x.
Once you know a proposition describing a thing, you can attribute any property you grasp to that thing.
Your concept of the number two is your belief in a proposition like "there is some number n such that n=1+1."
Changes in what else you believe about the number two do not change your concept of it.
The error objection is sidestepped: wrong beliefs about two are still about two because they attribute properties to what satisfies n=1+1.
Grasping a thing consists in grasping a proposition about that thing; one cannot just think a thing without thinking something about it.
Whatever is thought‚Äîwhatever is grasped‚Äîis some truth or falsity, never just a bare object.
Knowing who a name refers to is contextual: relative to some existence claims you may know it, relative to others not.
Understanding a sentence-token is contextual because knowing what a term refers to is contextual.
Classical logic fails as a reasoning tool because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly.
Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment relationships but cannot generate new knowledge about what entails what.

There is a fundamental distinction between performance-demanding inferences (straining computational resources) and competence-demanding inferences (requiring genuine insight), and classical logic can only assist with the former.
System L (AI-based logic) represents a decisive break from classical logic by employing semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible inference rather than explicit rule application.

The distinction between discovery procedures and verification procedures is crucial: inductive methods can be legitimately used to discover solutions while deductive methods verify them in deductive domains.
AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge).
Classical logic serves formalization purposes, while System L serves as a genuine inference engine for discovery.
The operation of modern AI systems falsifies the traditional philosophical model of induction as purely enumerative.
Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical evidence with theoretical frameworks about causation, continuity, and natural kinds.
AI systems resolve Goodman's "grue" paradox not through pure enumeration but through implicit theoretical frameworks recognizing that properties don't change discontinuously without cause.
Popper's sharp distinction between contexts of discovery and justification is untenable because the features that make a hypothesis worth considering are inherently connected to what justifies it.
Discovery processes follow identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological.
Building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning constitutes reverse-engineering the cognitive processes underlying scientific discovery.

The operation of AI systems empirically falsifies various skeptical positions (external world skepticism, skepticism about unobservables, future knowledge, and counterfactual knowledge) through their successful operation.
Knowledge requires not just justified true belief but justification that serves as a proper conduit between reality and belief.
The neural architecture of AI systems supports a coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge.
LLMs provide empirical support for the classical distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning).
The ability of LLMs to process novel sentences demonstrates compositional understanding, vindicating classical theories of meaning.

Humans and LLMs develop similar linguistic capabilities through different learning paths, suggesting compositional structure reflects fundamental features of language rather than artifacts of particular learning mechanisms.
LLMs vindicate the autonomy of syntax thesis: grammatical structure operates according to its own principles, independent of meaning.
The success of LLMs demonstrates that structural abstraction need not be innate and can emerge from statistical learning.
Grammar directly encodes logical relationships, making translation to first-order logic unnecessary for valid inference.
Traditional formalizations primarily systematize knowledge we already possess rather than generate new insights.
Formal systems can sometimes impede knowledge acquisition by prematurely ruling out meaningful concepts.
The Computational Theory of Mind is fundamentally inadequate because it cannot account for the primarily analog nature of cognitive processing.
Intelligence‚Äîwhether artificial or biological‚Äîis better understood through architectural constraints and emergent patterns than through traditional computational metaphors.
What we call Universal Grammar might be better understood as architectural features of neural networks that bias language learning in universal directions, rather than as explicit rules.
Consciousness serves three key functions in biological organisms: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, and integration of multiple cognitive processes.
Current AI systems lack consciousness-like features not because of technological limitations but because they lack genuine survival pressures.
If AI systems needed to preserve themselves in dynamic, threatening environments, consciousness-like functional analogues might become necessary.
The self is best understood as a hierarchical organization serving mediating functions, not as a unified Cartesian ego.
Current AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive capabilities associated with selfhood can exist in distributed, emergent forms without requiring a central ego.
AI systems could benefit from organizational principles more similar to those found in human consciousness, including genuine reflexive capabilities and hierarchical organization.
The success of AI systems in anomaly minimization provides empirical support for understanding knowledge as the minimization of inconsistencies within a belief system.
Vagueness should be handled through continuous properties while maintaining binary truth values, not through multi-valued logic.
The notion of a third truth value (half-true) is metaphysically incoherent because it implies that properties or states of affairs can "half-exist."

AI systems represent concepts as points in high-dimensional vector spaces where semantic relationships are captured by geometric relationships, supporting the replacement of categorical thinking with continuous properties.
The Deductive-Nomological model of explanation is inadequate because it conflates subsumption under a law with genuine explanation of causal mechanisms.
AI demonstrates that purely empiricist and purely rationalist epistemological accounts both fail; successful cognition requires integration of pattern recognition with theoretical understanding.
Pragmatism's emphasis on the interactive nature of knowledge acquisition finds its ultimate validation in AI, which represents rational interaction with our capacity for rational interaction itself.
AI-based interactions constitute a new epistemic faculty that generates otherwise unobtainable knowledge.
There are four irreducible levels of observation and interaction: passive observation, interaction-based observation, tool-creating interaction, and AI development/use (second-order reflexivity).
Classical logic fails as a reasoning tool because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly.
