The capacity for error is not just contingently but necessarily connected to rationality‚Äîthe very possibility of rationality requires the possibility of error.
System L employs semantic networks that represent concepts as nodes in a vast web of relationships capturing probabilistic associations, causal links, and analogical mappings.
Meta-reasoning patterns are higher-order templates for generating new inferences that go beyond simple deductive rules.
Defeasible reasoning‚Äîmaking provisional inferences that can later be revised‚Äîbetter mirrors actual human reasoning than classical logic's requirement for absolute certainty.
G√∂del demonstrated that not even arithmetic is recursively definable, making the reduction of mathematics to logic impossible in principle.
Understanding that a logical law validates an inference requires both first-order knowledge (recognizing the inference's validity) and second-order knowledge (understanding why it's valid).
If using a formal system requires us to already know what we're trying to find out, that system fails as a tool of discovery (the Prior Knowledge Principle).
If using a formal system to solve a problem is more difficult than solving that problem directly, that system fails as a tool of reasoning (the Efficiency Principle).
AI-logic can model counter-entropic processes while classical logic is limited to entropic processes.
AI-logic handles self-reference through probabilistic reasoning while classical logic falls into paradox or requires type restrictions.
The future of logic lies not in more sophisticated rule systems but in systems that better align with and augment natural reasoning processes.
AI systems develop rich representational networks where properties are understood as parts of interconnected causal systems, not merely counted occurrences.

AI systems develop strong biases toward properties that maintain stability across time and context‚Äîthey "learn" to be suspicious of properties that would involve discontinuous changes without causal explanation.
AI systems automatically develop representations that cluster properties into "natural kinds," with properties violating natural kind boundaries having lower probability.
The necessity of non-enumerative components in AI systems demonstrates the inadequacy of pure enumerative induction.
Even apparently simple statistical generalizations incorporate implicit theoretical components about causation, continuity, and explanation.
When AI learns that emeralds are green, it simultaneously learns that this color correlates with other physical and chemical properties, creating an implicit causal/explanatory network.
AI systems recognize patterns at multiple levels of abstraction, developing implicit understandings of which properties are more fundamental than others.
Complex, structured hypotheses cannot arise from random guessing‚Äîtheir generation necessarily involves principled reasoning guided by truth-tracking norms.
The traditional separation between psychology and logic of science is misguided because the mechanisms enabling successful scientific reasoning necessarily embody logical principles.
AI systems provide concrete, testable models of scientific reasoning that demonstrate sufficient principles for successful scientific discovery.
Treating perceptions as connected to external reality leads to reliable knowledge‚Äîif external world skepticism were correct, AI's consistent diagnostic success would be miraculous.

Modern AI systems at CERN routinely identify particle properties they've never directly "observed," demonstrating that knowledge of unobservables is routine when proper theoretical frameworks are in place.
When an AI system predicts hurricane paths with increasing accuracy, it demonstrates that knowledge of the future is possible through understanding causal mechanisms and continuities.
Counterfactual knowledge is grounded in understanding actual causal mechanisms‚ÄîAlphaGo's success demonstrates this by evaluating counterfactual game states.
Pure observation without conceptual frameworks is insufficient for understanding‚Äîeven simple perceptual knowledge requires theoretical frameworks.
Successful perception requires more than processing sensory data; conceptual understanding is essential for knowledge.
Modern medical AI systems outperform pure statistical approaches precisely because they incorporate theoretical understanding of disease mechanisms.
The ability of LLMs to draw valid inferences from semantically anomalous sentences demonstrates understanding of component meanings, grammatical structure, and compositional rules.
Humans and AI systems develop literal meaning as context-independent "default" meaning based on compositional structure, then modify this based on contextual factors.
The convergence of humans and LLMs on similar linguistic capabilities through different learning paths suggests these properties reflect fundamental features of language.
Abstract structural patterns emerge even from pure usage data and operate semi-autonomously while systematically constraining interpretation.
Abstract structure is real but emergent; syntax and semantics are separable but linked; statistical learning can yield systematic knowledge.
LLMs process noun phrases uniformly, handle predication consistently, and make valid inferences without transformation to logical form.
First-order logic-style representations are not necessary for valid inference; grammar directly guides inference without requiring translation.
Logical form is cognitively inert‚Äîpeople and LLMs reason without it, and it plays no role in actual inference.
Logical form is constructed rather than discovered‚Äîit requires prior understanding, systematizes rather than explains, and follows rather than guides comprehension.
Grammatical-logical alignment emerges naturally through statistical learning without explicit logical forms being needed.
Gettier cases fail to be knowledge because their justification involves unreliable patterns that aren't scalable across different situations.
AI systems evolve away from unreliable justificatory patterns that produce Gettier-like situations toward more robust knowledge representations.
Neural networks don't build knowledge from basic, self-evident truths but develop interconnected networks of mutual support like a "web of belief."
Knowledge emerges from patterns of activation across interconnected nodes, with each node's contribution depending on its connections to others.
Universal Grammar can be reconceptualized as constraints embedded in neural architecture rather than as a set of explicit rules.
The poverty of stimulus problem can be solved through architectural constraints that drastically reduce the hypothesis space children must explore during language acquisition.
Innate constraints can guide learning without requiring explicit representation‚Äîarchitectural features bias learning in universal directions.
Human cognition's most fundamental interactions with the world are inherently analog in nature; digital representations are derivative.
The process of converting analog sensory experiences into digital representations cannot itself be purely digital.
Neural networks operate in a fundamentally continuous rather than discrete manner, handling discrete symbolic representations through underlying analog processes.
The analog-like processing of neural networks emerges at a functional level regardless of the discrete nature of their physical implementation.
We should understand mind as a pattern-recognition system whose architecture constrains and guides the emergence of intelligent behavior rather than as a symbol-processing machine.
Learning involves the development of patterns within architecturally constrained networks that can become so deeply embedded they function like principles while remaining fundamentally pattern-based.
The ability to handle both analog and digital representations emerges from the properties of neural networks rather than requiring separate systems for each type of processing.
AI development should focus on architecture design rather than rule implementation.

Music exhibits parallels to language suggesting an analogous "Universal Musical Grammar" with universal features including octave equivalence, hierarchical phrase structure, and rhythmic organization.
Musical universals might reflect architectural features of auditory and temporal processing networks rather than explicit rules.
Both language and music share poverty of stimulus effects, critical periods, and hierarchical organization, strengthening the architectural interpretation.
Apparently rule-governed behaviors in both language and music can emerge from structured neural architectures without requiring explicit rule representation.
Real-time processing in consciousness occurs as a continuous stream of awareness integrating immediate visual awareness, instant recognition of danger, and real-time feedback‚Äînot as discrete steps.
Reflexive awareness allows consciousness to maintain ongoing awareness of internal states and integrate this with thought processes for immediate self-regulation.

Consciousness's most remarkable function is integrating multiple cognitive streams into unified experience‚Äîvisual tracking, proprioceptive awareness, memories, motor planning, and emotions come together in single unified experience.
Current AI systems process through separate, parallel modules rather than a unified workspace where all information comes together.
For current AI systems, a collision isn't "bad" in any meaningful way‚Äîit simply triggers pre-programmed response routines without the system needing to "care" about its continued existence.
Functional analogues to pain in AI systems would include unified damage-registration systems that immediately interrupt all other processes when damage occurs.
Functional analogues to emotion in AI systems would include action-guiding systems that shape behavior rather than just enabling emotion recognition and description.

Asking whether machines can be conscious in the human sense is less productive than asking what functional features of consciousness they might need to replicate to operate effectively in complex, dangerous environments.
The self or ego is best understood as an emergent property of pre-existing cognitive processes‚Äîa hierarchical organization based on survival value or other organizing principles.
The "sense of self" serves as a mediator between awareness of external events and internal states, giving rise to directives and intentions that help preserve the hierarchical organization.
One's sense of self is inherently reflexive, reflecting back on an already organized collection of mental entities, exercising causal power while being derivative rather than fundamental.
Weight-space proximity in neural networks creates "semantic topology" where functionally or meaningfully related elements cluster together in high-dimensional space.
Attention-based binding in transformer architectures creates measurable graphs of contextual relationships among elements‚Äîa form of active, context-dependent cohesion.
Loss-function optimization establishes persistent patterns of co-activation through prediction error minimization, creating stable cohesion relations.
A genuine functional analogue of ego in AI would require persistent organizational structure, genuine reflexive capabilities, and causal efficacy.
The DN model's emphasis on logical deduction from universal laws fails to capture how explanations actually work in both human cognition and AI systems.
Genuine explanation typically operates through pattern recognition, identification of local disruptions, and understanding of equilibrium states rather than formal deduction from laws.
We can readily identify causes of events without knowing complete psychological profiles or universal laws‚Äîno such universal laws exist for many human responses.
The DN model faces circularity: the only way to select relevant antecedent conditions is to already have understanding of what causes the type of event we're trying to explain.
Even physics learning begins with pattern recognition rather than formal laws‚ÄîNewton's laws formalized and systematized pre-existing causal knowledge.
Formal laws emerge from and systematize more basic causal understanding rather than grounding it.
Neural networks learn by minimizing loss functions‚Äîeffectively reducing prediction errors‚Äîparalleling the anomaly minimization principle.
Large language models make predictions by minimizing discontinuity with context, similar to how knowledge claims rest on minimizing anomalies in our web of understanding.
Concepts whose association would generate fewer anomalies are positioned closer together in AI embedding spaces, creating knowledge structures that mirror anomaly minimization.
Attention mechanisms weigh different parts of context in ways that minimize overall anomalies in predictions, demonstrating natural implementation of anomaly minimization.
In cases where direct verification is impossible, knowledge claims rest on recognizing that alternatives would generate far more anomalies and discontinuities in our web of understanding.
Multi-valued logic faces the problem that once we admit a third truth value, there's no principled reason to stop‚Äîleading to infinite regress undermining the explanatory value of truth values.
The notion of "half-existence" is metaphysically incoherent‚Äîsomething either exists or it doesn't.
Replacing categorical nouns with degree-adjectives aligns perfectly with how neural networks actually process information.
Modern convolutional neural networks compute continuous activation values across multiple features, effectively measuring degrees of properties rather than binary categories.
Language models represent words and concepts as high-dimensional vectors where semantic relationships are captured by continuous geometric relationships rather than discrete categories.
While fuzzy logic systems appear to implement multi-valued logic, they actually operate by measuring continuous properties and only discretizing results when necessary for practical decisions.
Human categorization involves prototype effects and graded membership, paralleling how AI systems operate with continuous rather than discrete categories.
The traditional pragmatist claim that truth is usefulness fails because usefulness varies by person and time while truth-values remain constant.
The pragmatist claim that people should search for usefulness rather than truth fails because valuable discoveries frequently emerge from pursuing seemingly useless knowledge.
Usefulness serves as a leading indicator of truth‚Äîwhen data is incomplete, the utility of a model suggests its likely truth.
Traditional epistemology's "view from nowhere" presents an unrealistic model of knowledge acquisition that fails to capture the essentially interactive nature of knowledge.
Knowledge seeks successful interaction with reality; empirical data is inherently interaction-dependent; even "objective" knowledge depends on interaction-based data.

Each level of interaction generates knowledge that cannot be obtained from lower levels‚ÄîLevel 2 requires actual interaction, Level 3 requires creating tools, Level 4 requires engaging with rationality itself.
Traditional computers execute predetermined operations quickly but cannot make novel inferences or demonstrate true adaptability‚Äîthey are tools of rationality but not rational agents.
AI uses non-deterministic, self-correcting protocols, generates unpredictable inferences, represents externalized but autonomous rationality, and can make inferences we might not or cannot make.
AI-based interactions generate truly novel empirical observations and create otherwise unobtainable knowledge.

Pragmatism, properly understood, was not just a theory of knowledge but a prescient description of knowledge's technological evolution.KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT CONCEPTUAL ATOMISM AND THE COMPUTATIONAL THEORY OF MIND
Content-externalism is false, but semantic externalism is true.
Content-externalism and semantic externalism are distinct doctrines that have been conflated in contemporary philosophy of mind.
Two brain-states can be qualitatively identical while having different semantic contents, but this applies only to linguistic meaning, not to mental content.
Mental content is not constitutively dependent on facts about one's environment in the way content-externalists claim.
Semantic externalism correctly holds that the truth-conditions of utterances containing proper names depend on facts about the referents of those names.
The apparent problems with semantic externalism (e.g., Frege puzzles about identity statements) vanish when we properly distinguish between semantic and conceptual analysis.
If content-externalism were true, then mental content would be without psychological significance, which contradicts the truism that beliefs, thoughts, and doubts are psychologically relevant.
The differences between Max and Twin-Max in thought experiments are like the differences in Poincar√©'s universe-expansion scenario‚Äîdistinctions without genuine differences.
One's knowing what an expression refers to always involves knowing some description that uniquely singles out its referent.
Ostensive definitions work through knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, not through direct acquaintance with referents.
There are three ways a proper name can be added to one's lexicon: ostensive definition, descriptive definition, and "picking up" the use‚Äîbut all three collapse into the descriptive.
Causal connections between subjects and referents are embedded in knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions containing context-sensitive expressions.
Russell's theory of descriptions is demonstrably false as a semantic analysis, though the distinction between semantic and conceptual analysis is crucial.
Content-externalism is incompatible with the Cartesian certainty of self-knowledge regarding one's own mental states.
If content-externalism were correct, one could mistake a non-thought for an actual thought, contradicting the immediacy of introspective access.
Burge's attempt to reconcile content-externalism with privileged access to one's own thoughts is fallacious because it restricts attention only to worlds where the relevant referent exists.
Functionalism cannot accommodate the causal potency of the mental because functional roles are not spatio-temporally located entities.
The Jackson-Pettit distinction between program causes and effective causes fails to save functionalism because program explanations of mental causation involve logical, not causal, guarantees.
A brain-state's having a certain functional role cannot be causally potent because functional role descriptions denote abstract relationships, not states of affairs.
The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because it involves fundamental misunderstandings of the concept of syntactic form.
A symbol-token is not purely morphological‚Äîthe psychological underpinnings of symbol production are constitutively involved in the tokening.
When a symbol-type is genuinely instantiated, a constituent of that instance includes aspects of the mind of the person producing the token.
Psychology cannot single-handedly transform an otherwise dead sound into a living symbol-token; both morphological and psychological aspects are necessary.
CTM's appeal to Ramsey-sentences to characterize mental states still fails because it reduces to a form of functionalism with the same fatal problems.
If content is causal role, then the same content cannot have different causal roles, but beliefs manifestly can have different causal roles in different contexts.
Conceptual atomism does not follow from conceptual-object atomism; even if concepts-as-objects lack structure, our mental representations of them may be structured.
Fodor's arguments against non-atomism fail because they conflate the information needed to lock onto a concept with information ascribed to that concept after lock-on.
Quine's arguments against the analytic-synthetic distinction are not cogent; analyticity can be understood without vicious circularity.
Inferential Role Semantics (IRA) is obviously false because inferences presuppose content‚Äînothing can have content in virtue of its inferential role.
Non-atomism is not equivalent to inferential role semantics and does not presuppose it.
Transitional Role Analysis (TRA) does not have the defects Fodor attributes to non-atomism, but it is still a form of functionalism and therefore false.
The systematicity of thought does not require that thought be conducted in a language; it can be explained without positing mental sentences.
The productivity of language is an aspect of its systematicity and does not support the Language of Thought hypothesis.
The conceptual/non-conceptual content distinction is genuine; perceptual content is fundamentally different from propositional content.
McDowell's arguments against the conceptual/non-conceptual distinction are fallacious; being able to refer to what one sees does not show that perception is structurally similar to language.
Sentences and perceptions have fundamentally different structures; demonstratives referring to specific perceptual features do not show that perception has sentential structure.
Peacocke's transitional role analysis of concepts fails because there is no non-arbitrary way to distinguish concept-constitutive transitions from merely habitual ones.
Any analysis of concepts in purely relational terms (concepts as nodes in networks of other concepts) cannot account for the fact that there are right and wrong ways to conceptualize experience.
Whether a certain kind of experience would confirm a certain empirical judgment is not ultimately an empirical matter but an analytic one.
Davidson's view that one must know a language to think is incompatible with the fact that linguistic competence must be mediated by cognitive processes.
Knowledge of language facilitates thought but cannot be constitutive of the ability to think, since thinking is a prerequisite to learning language.
Pre-linguistic creatures can have true and false mental contents; denying this is not a reasonable position.
Speaker's meaning presupposes conventional meaning; one cannot mean proposition P by producing noise N unless one believes N already means P.
Grice's theory of meaning fails because it is incompatible with the compositional character of sentence-meaning.
The differences between literal and communicated meaning can be explained pragmatically without adopting Russell's quantificational analysis of definite descriptions.
Propositions existed and had truth-values before there was thought; nobody grasped them before thought, but that is irrelevant to their existence.
The concept of a program-cause is important for explanation, but functionalists misuse it by applying it to relations that don't hold between genuine states of affairs.
Mental representation cannot be understood on the model of digital computation because computational operations presuppose semantic content rather than explaining it.
Narrow content exists and is shared by qualitatively identical individuals regardless of environmental differences.
Both soft content-externalism (two-tiered content) and hard-line content-externalism are false.
Fodor's strictly causal conception of conception follows logically from content-externalism, but both are mistaken.
For x to have a concept of y is not simply for some of x's states to have been caused by states of affairs involving y.
CTM, SCT, and hard-line content-externalism all presuppose conceptual atomism, which is false.
Conceptual non-atomism is correct: one's concept of Socrates necessarily requires possession of other concepts.
An otherwise conceptless creature could not have a concept of Socrates or any other object.
Perception is descriptive: a perception of an object gives one a description of that object.
One never sees bare things-in-themselves; what is visually represented are instances of properties and relations.
Sense-perceived particulars are represented in terms of instances of properties and relations, not as bare nouns.
The content of perception is given by existence-claims, not by mere nouns or proper names.
Expression-types must be distinguished from expression-tokens; the expression-type "I" doesn't refer to anyone.
What is literally meant by an utterance must be distinguished from the information uploaded in computing its literal meaning.
Even though "Smith" is a mere label semantically, one grasps this semantic rule through richly descriptive information.
One's knowing a semantic rule like "'Smith' refers to x" requires knowing who Smith is through uniquely individuating descriptions.
The information conveyed by a sentence-token differs from its literal meaning because of how semantic rules are accessed.
Our modal intuitions about proper names are consistent with grasping their semantics through descriptive information.
Mental content is not object-involving: external objects are not literal constituents of perceptual or thought content.
The content-externalist's claim that Mary herself is part of a visual perception's content is false.
Kripke's arguments against descriptivism about reference are correct, but they do not refute descriptivism about concepts.
The semantic and epistemological consequences of Kripke's arguments have been conflated.
The causal theory of reference is only a chapter in the descriptive story, not a replacement for it.
Causal connections between subjects and referents are always embedded in knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions.
One can use a proper name to refer to someone without knowing any description that the person uniquely satisfies in an encyclopedic sense.
When one "picks up" a name from conversation, one acquires knowledge of a description like "the person Smith was describing on occasion t."
The description through which one initially locks onto an object need not be informative about the object's essential properties.
There is no vicious circularity in the claim that name-appropriation always involves knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions.
Russell's conception of singular or direct reference was entirely correct; his error was misapplying it.
Russell wrongly thought that actual cases of genuine reference were almost never found in everyday discourse.
Frege's theory of sense and reference, insofar as it applies to definite descriptions, is really a confused version of Russell's theory.
Fregean "indirect reference" is not meaningfully different from quantification.
The fundamental constituents of reality are not rocks, trees, and people, but instances of properties.
Socrates' existence supervenes on facts about property-instances, ultimately on states of affairs without objects.
One can in principle grasp a proposition whose truth presupposes Socrates' existence, but this doesn't validate content-externalism.
The propositions through which we actually grasp external objects are purely descriptive existence-claims.
Because light travels at a finite speed, anything one sees has ceased to exist by the time one perceives it.
The distinction between types and tokens must be made universally for sentences, given that all natural language sentences are tensed.
The meaning of a sentence-type is not a proposition but a function that assigns propositions to tokens.
Definite descriptions are directly referential singular terms, not quantifier phrases as Russell claimed.
The differences between what tokens of definite descriptions communicate and their literal meanings are pragmatic, not semantic.
Russell's theory of descriptions is unnecessary for explaining cognitive significance and is demonstrably false as semantic analysis.
Semantic analysis (identifying literal meanings) must be distinguished from conceptual analysis (identifying logically equivalent but more perspicuous propositions).
Wide-scope and narrow-scope readings of belief attributions are explained by pragmatics, not by Russell's quantificational semantics.
One can think about future individuals like "the first baby born in the 22nd century" through uniquely individuating descriptions.
Concepts of spatiotemporal objects require causal connections between subject and object, but concepts of abstract objects do not.
Evans' notion of "discriminating knowledge" correctly captures that conception requires more than mere causal connection.
Spatiotemporal individuals are distinguished by their locations, so discriminating knowledge involves spatio-temporal information.
A concept of an object is not identical with knowledge of any single existence-claim but with a series of interlocking existence-claims.
One's concept of Fred evolves continuously through replacement of existence-claims while maintaining numerical identity.
The existence-claims through which one initially locks onto an object are typically forgotten and replaced.
A concept persists through changes in the particular existence-claims through which it is sustained, like a person persisting through change.
Frege's puzzle about identity (Hesperus = Phosphorus) is solved by recognizing different knowledge-streams for the same referent.
Evans' notion of a de re sense is incoherent because the proposition meant cannot have the descriptive mode of presentation as a component.
Evans conflates semantics with pre-semantics: the descriptive information through which we compute meaning is not part of literal meaning.
One need not revise the principle that believing P and not-P is irrational; content-externalism's revision is unnecessary.
What one believes are existence-claims describing singular propositions, not the singular propositions themselves.
Linguistic communication does not require speaker and auditor to associate identical propositions with utterances.
Communication requires only identity of truth-maker between speaker's and auditor's thoughts, not identity of proposition.
The naive model of communication (requiring identical propositions) is a non-starter given the public nature of language.
Language cuts through biographical differences because linguistic communication concerns identity of truth-maker, not of proposition.
Content-externalism entails a self-contradiction: two people with identical beliefs can differ in what they believe.
For two people to be in epistemically identical situations just is for them to have the same beliefs.

**God, though supreme, belonged to a "council of Gods"**‚Äîhis relationship to council members was that of chairman to board-member, not lord to vassal.
**God's powers are limited**: He cannot do away with human freedom without doing away with human beings themselves.
**God has emotions because he is not all-powerful**. He is sufficiently lacking in power that his psychological constitution is still basically that of a human being.
**God is capable of changing**. A being that doesn't change at all is completely unresponsive to us and doesn't care for us.
**God is "immanent" in the spatiotemporal world**‚Äîpresent throughout it, like gravity or light.
**All reality is animate**; reality consists of consciousness individuated into discrete consciousnesses.
**God is but one of the many consciousnesses into which generalized consciousness is individuated**, with the qualification that he is the most important one.
**God, Jesus, and the Holy Ghost are distinct entities** (trinitarianism, not unitarianism).
**God, Jesus, and the Holy Ghost jointly constitute a single "Godhead"** despite being distinct.
**Both God and Jesus are corporeal**.
**God himself has a father**.
**Theses 2-5 are corollaries of thesis 1** (God was once a man). The five theses form a logically unified system.
**Smith was presenting a vision, not conclusions of arguments**. The arguments, even if cogent, wouldn't lead anyone to accept such a vision.
**The merits of Smith's vision lie in the vision itself**, not in his arguments for it.
**Smith's philosophical arguments are more compelling than his exegetical arguments**.
**Smith produced exegetical arguments after philosophical insights had already led him to accept his positions**.
**Smith's philosophical insights were coded into a religious epiphany**‚Äîthey would not otherwise have compelled him to break so completely from Christian orthodoxy.
**Smith likely arrived at his doctrines instantaneously** as part of a religious epiphany at age 14.
**Smith held his tongue over the next few decades**, speaking his mind only after acquiring standing and suspecting he had only a short time to live.
**Smith's central question**: What must God be like if human beings are to have the kind of relationship with him that they are supposed to have?
**In taking this question as primary, Smith broke with both Christian and philosophical tradition**.
**Smith's theology is not concerned with providing logical proofs of God's existence**. God is known through revelation or testimony.
**Attempts to prove God exists inevitably turn Him into an impersonal force or principle**, stripping him of his ability to have a relationship with us.
**If "God" is "a maximally perfect being," "a guarantor of natural law," or an "unmoved mover," he is unlikely to be sufficiently like us to have a meaningful relationship with us**.
**Smith attributes only as much power and sapience to God as is compatible with God being our guardian**.
**God needn't be absolutely powerful and knowing‚Äîonly relatively so**. From the viewpoint of a religious person, God's primary function is to guide and care for us.
**Orthodox Christian theology has incompatible mandates**: God is supposed to be all-knowing and all-powerful, yet also supposed to care about us.
**Orthodox Christianity suffers from incoherence because it starts with the supposition that God is perfect** and then tries to validate the presumption that God is emotionally invested in us.
**An all-powerful, all-knowing being wouldn't have emotions** and therefore wouldn't have any emotions concerning us.
**The concept of a sapient, all-powerful being is incoherent**.

**Sapience involves being responsive to change; being responsive to change involves being vulnerable; being vulnerable involves not being all-powerful**. Therefore, sapience is incompatible with omnipotence.
**According to orthodox Christian theology, God has a human son but is not himself human or otherwise biological, which is absurd**.
**God and Jesus, though related as father and son, are supposed to be one entity, which is absurd**.
**Orthodox Christian theology is incorrigibly incoherent**, and the reason is that it starts with the incoherent supposition that God is absolutely perfect.
**An all-knowing creature wouldn't care about us**, for it would have no emotions at all‚Äîemotion presupposes partiality and therefore ignorance.
**An all-powerful being wouldn't care about us**, for such a being would have no vulnerabilities and therefore none of the emotions that presuppose vulnerability.
**If one's starting point is that God is all powerful or all-knowing or otherwise perfect, there is no way to explain why he would care about us**.
**Smith's theology is free from the incoherencies of orthodox Christian theology**.
**Smith starts with the supposition that God is our guardian**, attributing only as much power and sapience as is compatible with that supposition.
**A God that cares about us must be capable of changing and evolving**.
**God is a highly evolved person**‚Äîa being that started off as a person and developed into a God.
**Smith's theology, unlike orthodox Christian theology, is compatible with the fact that Jesus, God's alleged son, is a person**.
**God and Jesus are distinct in Smith's theology, as they must be, given that they are related as father and son**.
**Smith sidesteps the problem of theodicy** not by reconciling evil with an all-powerful God but by denying that God is all-powerful.

**Smith validates religious practice**: From the viewpoint of a religious person, God's primary function is to guide and care for us, so he must be relatively powerful and knowing, but needn't be absolutely so.
**Christianity isn't strictly monotheistic**: There is a single supreme divine being, but there are at least three divine beings.
**Smith is simply calling Christianity out on this fact**.
**If Jesus really is the son of God, then God is human. And if God is human, then humans can become gods**.
**Christianity may represent a revival of polytheistic instincts**.
**Early Doctors of the Church needed at least two divinities, God and Jesus**, since Jesus's divinity is the cornerstone of Christianity, but they did not want to openly embrace polytheism.
**Church Doctors affirmed, absurdly, that God and Jesus, though two, are one**.
**The Holy Ghost was posited as a way to let God and Jesus be one**: though obviously distinct, they both partake of this "Holy Spirit."
**After being posited, the Holy Ghost became a third divinity**, forcing Church Fathers to say that God, Jesus, and the Holy Ghost, though three, are one.
**Minds can change but cannot be assembled**. Therefore, they either exist or they don't; if they do, they have always existed.
**God cannot bring people into existence**. God is omnipotent in the sense that he can do whatever can be done, not in the sense that he can do what is logically impossible.
**The doctrine of pre-existence is heretical** relative to Christian orthodoxy.
**The doctrine implies that God's power is limited**.
**The doctrine puts people on the same footing as God**. If people have always existed alongside God, they are in some respect his peers.
**The doctrine has roots in Western philosophy**: Leibniz held that minds are "monads" that cannot be created or destroyed; Plato held that minds are "simples" that exist eternally.
**The history of Mormon theology is a history of attempts to run away from Smith's thought under the pretext of developing it**.

**Post-Smith Mormon theologians were less willing than Smith to depart from Christian orthodoxy** and therefore had difficulty compatibilizing Smith's doctrines with what they wanted Mormon theology to be.
**Mormon theologians were under pressure to accept Smith's doctrines** given that KFD is to a large extent definitive of Mormon theology.
**Mormon theology as a whole has remained in a limbo** between Smith's own theology and softened versions of it.
**Even the most "Smith-positive" Mormon theologians, like Orson Pratt, repudiate the very essence of Smith's theology**‚Äîthe contention that God was once a man.
**Pratt's position (pantheism coupled with sentient matter) is very far from‚Äîand logically incompatible with‚ÄîSmith's position that some person became what is now God**.
**This shows how intensely Mormon theologians resisted Smith's doctrines**, even while having to operate within a framework at least partially defined by them.
**KFD did more than any of Smith's previous sermons to shape Mormon thought**, because in it Smith united his positions into a single coherent vision.
**Smith had publicly endorsed each of his main doctrines before giving the KFD**, which is why many in the early Mormon Church regarded him as a "heretic" and "blasphemer."
**Despite intense pressure, Smith never softened his positions**.
**"Paracletes" does not provide a useful illustration of Smith's thought: it actually obscures it**.
**The material on which "Paracletes" is based is drawn from the periphery of Smith's thought**, but it treats it as central.
**"Paracletes" makes Smith's theology seem cartoonish and arbitrary**.
**"Paracletes" spins off a defensible idea into an L. Ron Hubbard-style fantasy**.
**Brown's contention that "Paracletes" provides a crucial window on the complex network of beliefs undergirding Smith's theology is not accurate**.
**Smith's theology is cogent and carefully thought-out**, not an absurd fairy tale spun out of whole cloth (contrary to what Phelps's fiction suggests).
**Works discussing theological development should be examined in chronological order**, noting where a given work either builds on or diverges from its predecessors.
**The assumption that the Bible is literally accurate represents one possible starting point** for Smith's reasoning.

**Van Hale's position that Smith arrived at his doctrines gradually is consistent with Smith's sermons**‚Äîbut another possibility is that Smith had already completely accepted them but refrained from stating them directly.
**A follow-up paper is warranted** investigating the question: Is anything left of Smith's thought in contemporary Mormon theology?
**"As man is, God once was; as God is, man may become"** (Lorenzo Snow's aphorism, endorsed as capturing the essence of Smith's theology).
**God is an evolved man, and a human being can evolve into a state of relative Godliness**.
**Godliness comes in degrees**; there are, or could be, various beings having varying degrees of God-status.
**Unless God is at least partly human, he is unlikely to have the ability or inclination to function as our guardian**.

Intentions are judgments as to how to consolidate one's psychological architecture.
Values are beliefs as to what, in general, is conducive to the integrity of one's psychological architecture.
Freedom is a property of actions and also of desires, contrary to Locke's claim that it applies only to actions.
Second-order desires do not collapse into first-order desires; the distinction is meaningful and important.
Persons, unlike non-persons, subject their own desires and mental states to critical rational scrutiny.
Rational conduct is not identical with intelligent conduct; an act can be highly intelligent yet irrational.
An irrational act is one that does not embody due regard for one's various interests, regardless of its intelligence.
For an act to be free, one's first-order desires must be consistent with the second-order desires driving that act.
Higher-order desires can become mere vehicles for first-order desires through psychological warping.
Truly free acts are driven by values, not merely by higher-order desires.
Values are not desires, though values may lead to desires and desires may lead to values.
Where there are no values, there are no selves, though there may be minds.
There is no agency of any kind where there are no selves.
Estrangement from one's own actions amounts to estrangement from all of one's own desires.
Being free consists primarily in being oneself, and secondarily in being able to do what one wants.
Many analyses that philosophers put forth seem not to embody genuine attempts to find the truth; Frankfurt's analysis of freedom does embody such an attempt.
Kant's two categorical imperatives (universalizability and respect for autonomy) are not equivalent.
Acts of con-artistry would not necessarily be self-defeating in a world of con-artists, refuting Kant's CI1.
Morally good forms of conduct can be ones that, if engaged in universally, could not be successfully carried out.
A moral principle outweighed is not a moral principle extinguished.
A categorical moral obligation can be outweighed by some other, stronger obligation without ceasing to exist.
Kant's failure to distinguish the good from the praiseworthy is a fundamental blunder in his ethical theory.
Many things that are morally good are not commendable; Brown's happiness is good but not praiseworthy.
Intelligence, wealth, and health have inherent moral value, contrary to Kant's claim that only good will has moral worth.
Wittgenstein's central claims about meaning and mind are demonstrably false.
Norman Malcolm's denial that people dream was a consequence of following Wittgenstein's false views about mental processes.
Ryle's claim that the difference between voluntary and involuntary actions concerns cultural acceptability rather than mental states is obviously false.
First-class philosophical thinkers are more likely to use their intelligence to defend orthodoxies than to look for truth.
Students and professors at first-tier philosophy institutions are not more likely to produce better work than their counterparts at bottom-tier universities.
Strawson's ascriptivist analysis of moral responsibility is false because it makes intentions irrelevant to responsibility.
Strawson's expressivist claim that "true" is redundant is false; "everything Plato said was true" cannot be stated without "true" or a synonym.
"It is true that snow is white" and "snow is white" are not synonymous; the former concerns a proposition while the latter concerns snow directly.
Wittgenstein's claim that "I am in pain" is merely expressive behavior like animal howling is demonstrably false.
Austin's performative utterance theory is false; utterances like "I promise" do affirm propositions.
Embedding a sentence P in "if P, then Q" does not change P's meaning; this is necessary for indirect arguments to work.
A priori knowledge is knowledge that does not depend on sensory observation for its justification.
All mathematical truths are analytic truths.
Not all analytic truths are mathematical truths; statements about mathematics are analytic but not themselves mathematical.
No analytic truths are tautologies, since tautologies are definitional truths that hold in virtue of contingent facts about word usage.
The statement "a bachelor is an unmarried man" is an empirical truth about language, not an analytic truth.
It is incoherent to deny analytic truths, but one can coherently (though incorrectly) deny definitional truths.
G√∂del proved that the truths of arithmetic are analytically true but not formally true.
What G√∂del proved is that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths of arithmetic, not that mathematical truths are non-analytic.
Incompleteness is the property of a statement-set having no recursive definition.
Most scientifically important statement-sets are incomplete; statement-sets with real scope or explanatory power cannot be axiomatized.
There is no recursive definition of the class of statements of the form "x is a real number."
A logic (system of logic) is a recursively defined statement-set.
The class of all recursively defined statement-sets is not itself recursively definable.
There is no recursive characterization of the concept of logical truth.
The incompleteness of logic is more general, and perhaps more significant, than the incompleteness of arithmetic.**Positions Identified in "Ninety Paradoxes of Philosophy and Psychology"**

**Each of James's five core pragmatist theses (i)-(v) is false.** However, they are "distorted ways of expressing a number of legitimate insights concerning knowledge and the acquisition thereof."
**Pragmatism conflates epistemology with metaphysics/ontology.** What pragmatists incorrectly represent as claims about truth itself are actually claims about our knowledge of truth.
**The meaning of a hypothesis is NOT identical to its observable consequences.** The relationship between a hypothesis and its observable consequences is always contingent, never analytic.
**Observable consequences depend on operative conditions and causal mechanisms.** Different conditions or mechanisms would yield different observational consequences from the same hypothesis.
**One can accept a hypothesis H while denying any particular specification of its observable consequences O^ without contradiction.** This proves H is not equivalent to O^.
**What (i) distortedly expresses is the truism (i+): "Our knowledge of the veracity of a given hypothesis is based on its observable consequences."** This is true but utterly truistic.
**Observable consequences are the "vector sum" of what a hypothesis says AND the subject's relationship to the alleged reality.** They are not purely a function of the hypothesis itself.
**It is not truth that is empowering; it is knowledge.** Truths are useless unless known.
**The property of being power-enhancing belongs to our knowledge of truths, not to those truths per se.**
**What (ii) distortedly expresses is (ii+): "Instances of knowledge are ipso facto empowering."** The pragmatist incorrectly attributes to truth what is actually a property of knowledge.
**There are highly assimilable false ideas and highly non-assimilable true ones.** (iii) is at best a half-truth.
**The pragmatist version (iii*), that truth IS assimilability, is an "outright falsehood."**
**What (iii) distortedly expresses is (iii+): "Knowledge is assimilated truth, and beliefs become increasingly knowledge-constitutive as they become increasingly grounded."**
**(iv) is false taken literally.** An idea is either true or false; it does not become true.

**What (iv) distortedly expresses is (iv+): "The property of being true doesn't have any value until an idea that has that property becomes a piece of knowledge."** The value of trueness eventuates when truth is acquired/known.
**(v) is "clearly false."** Truth is discovered, not made.
**What (v) distortedly expresses is (v+): "Knowledge is made, not discovered."** We construct knowledge (through operations on data), even though we discover truth.
**(v+) is "eminently defensible."**
**Pragmatism systematically confuses properties of truth with properties of knowledge.** Each pragmatist thesis takes something true of knowledge and falsely attributes it to truth itself.
**Pragmatism replaces an object-oriented conception of knowledge with a subject-oriented (agent-oriented) conception.** This is what (i)-(v) have in common.
**Pragmatism combats an "intellectualist" conception of knowledge and replaces it with an "interactionist" or "operationalist" conception.**
**The negations of (i)-(v) are each correct.** But they *suggest* (without implying) that knowledge-acquisition is purely passive reception.
**Classical Epistemology (CE)‚Äîthat knowledge-acquisition is about passively taking in what exists‚Äîmay be true in some narrow technical sense, but it is misleading.**
**Intellectual discoveries are made by solving practical problems.** Insights are the "collateral damage" of workarounds to practical roadblocks.
**Much of physics is fallout from attempts to create better weapons, dams, etc.** Mathematics is constructed to validate this fallout.
**Economics was invented to manage the influx of wealth from the New World into Europe.**
**Anthropology was invented to help Europeans interact more productively with colonized peoples.**
**Psychoanalysis was developed to solve otherwise unsolvable psychiatric problems.**

**Even "purely philosophical" problems are not purely philosophical.** Modern epistemology arose in the mid-1600s precisely when modern physics and engineering arose, and when Church doctrines were losing credibility because they interfered with scientific progress.
**Cartesian skepticism and Lockean empiricism arose because faith-based epistemology was no longer viable.**
**Modern logic began with Boole in the mid-1800s, with the objective of automating reasoning, precisely when physical production was being automated.** This is not coincidental.
**"Purely theoretical" problems are problems relating to the mutual coherence of discoveries made in the course of solving practical problems.**
**Calculus was invented to compute planetary orbits and ballistics.** "Purely theoretical" questions (infinitesimals, fractals) arose to validate an enormously useful belief-system.
**"Purely theoretical" knowledge, insofar as it exists, tends to be stale and one-dimensional.**
**"Book knowledge" of principles proves useless in practice.** One learns formalisms based on principles, not the principles themselves, until forced to relearn them through practical application.
**"Pure theory" tends to concern itself with mere schemata.** Consequently, "theoretical knowledge" degenerates when not anchored in practical knowledge.
**Ideas are NOT true because they are useful (contra James).** The theorems of trigonometry are useful because they are true, not the other way around.
**However, truths are learned‚Äîand are worth learning‚Äîbecause they are useful.** It is not absurd to identify the true *insofar as it is worth learning* with the useful.
**Theoretical knowledge should exist only as long as it is anchored in practical knowledge.** When it ceases to be so anchored, it degenerates into knowledge of empty formalisms.
**Truth is objective.** Either there is an even number of stars in the galaxy or there isn't, regardless of whether this is worth knowing.
**Knowledge is a relationship between subject and object (mind and world), and therefore has a subjective side.**
**The intellect exists biologically to help the organism survive and procreate.**
**In human beings, intellect has to some extent become autonomous.** Pure mathematicians study relations "for their own sake."
**Even autonomous intellectual pursuits investigate coherence-relations internal to datasets that are themselves of interest only because of practical applications.**
**The pure mathematician/philosopher studies coherence-relations within practically-originated datasets.**
**The theoretician is to the practitioner what the martial artist is to the soldier.** The theoretician exercises the ability to do what the practitioner is already doing.
**It is the practitioner who determines both what the theoretician studies and the general lines along which he studies it.**
**The artist, like the engineer, organizes matter (paint, marble, sound).** But the artist is interested in material relations "for their own sake" rather than for practical applications.
**The artist is interested either in deepening understanding of material relations or in exercising his ability to understand them.**
**The artist appears to have turned his back on reality only because he is exercising his ability to engage it.** The same holds of the theoretician.

**Interest in truth or beauty "for their own sake," though not directly concerned with practical results, is directly concerned with the cognitive basis of our ability to generate practical results.**
**James's thesis that truth is utility, though false, may be regarded as a distorted expression of the truth that theoretical activity is indirectly practical.**
